ResponsesInList.Text: Dear All: I set up a course and built some content in it, such as scorm package, webpage content, and so on. If I want to move part of the content to another course, can anyone suggest a easy way instead of rebuild it again. Please do help! Thank you very much! Joann

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I move part of the course to another course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joann I don't think your question has anything to do with the Moodle Lesson activity. Please re-post it to the General Problems forum. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I move part of the course to another course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joann, You can move content from any course into a new or existing course using the import feature available in the administration block.   Just be careful when using this feature - if you cancel an import, the course you are copying from duplicates itself!

ResponsesInList.Title: lesson config - correct answer moves forward, incorrect forced backward
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello All, I've posted in "general", and it looks like my question may belong in the lesson module discussion. I'm trying to figure out what I'm doing wrong. I'm trying to set up my course so that if a student gets a correct answer he/she can move forward, but if he/she gets an incorrect answer, he/she is forced to a slide with the necessary info then allowed to retake the question/quiz. Would be nice if the student could, upon failing a question/quiz, be directed to the pertinent info then return directly to where he/she left off (i.e. the same question/quiz). In other words, I'd like it if they didn't have to go back in the course and have to go though multiple slides to return to where they were at in a series of questions/quizzes... any help is appreciated! adam my attempt can be seen at: publicadjustertraining.com/onlineclasses/ thx

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: lesson config - correct answer moves forward, incorrect forced backward
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Adam, Looks to me like you got the effect. You have a series of branch tables, then some questions. Wrong answers in a single question jump to the same Branch page with more info, which takes the student back to the question they missed. Once the student selects the correct answer, they move to the next question. What is there in the lesson could be your entire lesson or your first lesson segment. If it is a segment, you will put in a branch table at the end of the current logical order and your last question correct answer will jump here. Make it the intro to the next lesson segment, choice to continue, go to the end of lesson, go to the branch table (you don't have yet) that serves as the table of content for the lesson at the start. I also like a branch table at my end of lesson, titled End of This Lesson which has words about what they just learned and their next step. The choice takes them back to the TOC or the real end of lesson screen via the standard choice of that name.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: lesson config - correct answer moves forward, incorrect forced backward
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, thanks for the info. And everyone - thanks much. I think I have it figured out now! Peace, A

When creating a mc question my feedback/response for the right answer is given, but if somebody has chosen a false answer they get the default feedback anyway, even though I have set an individual feedback. All jumps from wrong answers go to the same page. Even tried to put the same feedback to all wrong answers, but it still does not work. Any suggestions? Thank you very much, Katja

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: multiple choice: feedback to incorrect answers
ResponsesInList.Text: I found the problem: all MC answers (correct and incorrect) must be set to 'jump to next page'. It is now no longer possible to go back and retry the MC question, but the individual feedback that fits to the chosen answer (whether correct or incorrect) will be displayed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: multiple choice: feedback to incorrect answers
ResponsesInList.Text: katja: " I found the problem: all MC answers (correct and incorrect) must be set to 'jump to next page ." This is not the way MCQ questions are supposed to work in the Lesson module! Correct answers must be set to "jump to next page" and incorrect ones to "jump to this page". You must have "played" with the other Lesson settings somewhere (there are so many parameters...). Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: multiple choice: feedback to incorrect answers
ResponsesInList.Text: Why do wrong answers have to stay on "this page"? I would like to have students see the feedback, but not allow them to go back and redo the questions/answers. Anyway this can be changed? (running Moodle 1.9.5) Carrie

ResponsesInList.Title: Matching question problem in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have one problem with matching question. When this type of question is graded, it is always evaluated with 0 points if I have at least 1 mistake. If all answers are right grade is also ok - Full points. Is it normal? Why the final grade is not calculated from number of right and bad answers? Thanx

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Matching question problem in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jarsolav, Currently the matching question type is all or nothing. Why the final grade is not calculated f rom number of right and bad answers? The original Lesson counted answers as right or wrong based on the jump.  So forward progression in the Lesson was a correct answer and staying on the current page or moving backward in the Lesson was an incorrect answer.  So, this was an "all or nothing" system.  When custom scoring was introduced, the all or nothing method was still being used to allow for fewer discrepancies between the two scoring systems. Another reason is that you would have to assign a score for every correct match and every incorrect match.  This might become more complicated than what most users want.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Matching question problem in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for advices, but I dont know what I am doing bad. I turn off custom scoring, and add multianswer question. There are 4 answer. 3 are right, 1 wrong. I set up jumps - next page for correct answers, this page for wrong. If I try to go through lesson and answer by checking any combinations, results are always 0% or 100%. What i am doing bad. Thnx

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Matching question problem in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jaroslav, if you are using Multianswer, that is also 'all or nothing'. Click on the Help icon next to the Multianswer option for more. If you use Multichoice without Multianswer checked, then the student can only click on one of the choices at a time.

The first thing to do when you get a blank page in Moodle is to go Administration / ► Server ► Debugging and to switch Debug messages to ALL: Show all reasonable PHP debug messages. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need solution when no more unseen questions in a cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Kimber, I am having the exact same problem. I made a test Lesson with a cluster to figure it out. What I've learned is that it seems to behave properly when you're previewing it as a teacher (because it replaces the "Jump to Unseen Question in Cluster" jump with "Next Page" jumps). However, when you switch your role to student, and have seen all of the questions*, it dumps me to an error without showing me the last content page of the Lesson ("Could not find lesson pages"). If I click on Continue at this point, it dumps me to the Site Home, and the course I was just working in no longer shows up in the "All Courses" list. That bit is especially weird. The structure of my Lesson is: 1st content page (CP1): Jumps to "Next Page" which is the beginning of the Cluster Cluster: Jumps to "Unseen quustion within a cluster" Question Page 1 (QP1): Right answer jump: "Unseen question within a cluster", wrong answer jump: "1st content page" Question Page 2: (QP2): Right answer jump: "Unseen question within a cluster", wrong answer jump: "1st content page" End of cluster: Jumps to "Next page" Last content page (Jump to "End of Lesson") * As an example, if I deliberately answer the first QP (let's say QP1) it gives me wrong, go back to CP1 and click continue, then answer QP2 wrong, back to CP1  and click continue, it errors out ("Could not find lesson pages.") I can get that to happen every time. The same thing happens if I click the correct response on one of the questions, which takes me to the next question, then click the wrong answer, get taken back to CP1, then click "Continue." And, oddly enough, if I get both questions correct, it completely skips the last Content Page and takes me directly to the End of Lesson page. As a side note, I'm not clear on how the Cluster "Unseen Question" jump is supposed to work. Does it mean actually "seeing it" and not "seeing it and getting the question right"? How do I make sure that the student has to get the questions right before moving on in a Cluster situation?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need solution when no more unseen questions in a cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Note 1: I've managed to find a lot of people on the forums who suggest shying away from using Clusters at all, which just gives me a huge boost of confidence! Really, I just found a teacher who, in an effort to force Moodle to do what he wanted, had placed a content page, then a question page, then REPEATED the content page, then another question page. The first QP, if answered correctly, jumped to QP2, and if they got that one WRONG, it jumped to the repeat of the content page, so when the student pressed "Next," they didn't have to answer QP1 again, just go directly into QP2. This seemed just a bit inefficient, and I thought Clusters would help me out here. Note 2: Those same people suggested that, to test out clusters, you use an actual student account instead of just changing your role to a student. I did this, and got the exact same same results as above.

ResponsesInList.Title: Newbie help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: First of all Hi there to everyone! I've setup a local Moodle system to proof test it with a view ti using it for my comapnies online web courses. I've tried seaching the forums and documentation, to no avail. We have copious course documents in Word and PDF format at the moment, and would like to move this content into Moodle, roughtly 1 chapter = 1 lesson. Is there anyway to easily do this and retain the formatting, esp around screenshots with arrows and description around them? Many thanks, in advance, for any assistance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Newbie help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello and welcome Richard! I have some not very good news for you I'm afraid.Not want you want to hear with an early posting. Mind you, there's usually a way of doing/solving everything in Moodle, with a bit of creativity, even if it's not the ideal method! The only import option is powerpoint (and if you are using Moodle version 1.9 or below this basically doesn't work anyway). Firstly copying straight from Word is not great as Word adds tons of extraneous code. There is a Word code stripper in the Moodle editor but this is not infallible, so it's better to copy the Word file, then past into word pad or note pad, convert to plain text and copy that before pasting into a lesson. This is likely to lose you your graphics. A quick and dirty solution is to save each pdf page (and convert your word files to pdfs too for this same purpose) as an image file and then just have that image file only within a lesson page. I've already posted some info about this in a previous thread (you'll need to read both my posts in here as I've also suggested a way to speed this process up). If you save pdfs as images and import them, you will retain the crucial formatting and image positioning. Another alternative is don't have lessons, convert the pdfs (and also save the word docs as pdfs first too) and save/share these as movie files and get the students to work through them screen by screen. Sorry it's not great; this is a common ask in here. BTW I hope you mean '= 1 lesson page' not '1 lesson' otherwise you must have humungous Word files. Lynn Scarlet

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Newbie help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard, Lynn's given you some good advice but I'm just going to add a couple of alternative thoughts: your PDF files can be split into chapters; there are free utilities that will do this. Google "pdf splitter" and you'll find a bunch. In your situation, you might want to attach the chapter as a resource in this form. You can also, obviously split the PDF more granularly (if that's a word?) than chapter, and some of the utilities probably have a feature to automatically split all the pages. This might be preferable to exporting as an image; the quality of the resulting small PDFs is usually higher than the same PDF exported as an image. Your PDF can be referenced by the lesson in the "pop-to file or web page" option, or as a URL - you obviously need to host the PDF on your moodle site. While it's true that Word adds too much cr*p formatting to be "copied and pasted" into Moodle directly, there is a way to create cleaner HTML out of Word and then bring the result in without the extraneous junk: Start by using Word's "Save As Filtered HTML" option. This had different names in different versions of Word, but basically gets rid of a lot of the Word-specific junk. Now it's actually pretty good. But you can run a utility on this to make it better. Dreamweaver has a great "Clean up Word formatting" option, if you have that, or google "clean word html" and you'll see a bunch of free tools on line. But the "granddaddy" of these tools is HTMLTidy. Here's a nice little blog post on using HTMLTidy options to deal with Word HTML. http://www.rogerobeid.com/2011/02/24/clean-up-microsoft-word-html/ At this point you have a really good html document as your source. If you copy and paste it You still may have to chop it up into "chapters", if I understand you correctly, but you could then: use the "popup to file or web page" for the lesson to reference that "chapter" (IOW host the HTML you created; see next point). add the file as a URL resource if you host what you have created (NB: do *not* forget the folder of images that is created in tandem with the HTML file) copy and paste into the Moodle editor after opening the cleaned HTML in Word or browser -- I'm pretty sure you'll have to re-insert/ upload the images, however You can also export (Save As) Word documents as PDFs, and then chunk them up and use directly as embedded resources. I would recommend this, because it will give you one process to follow for all these documents if you handle them *all* as PDFs, whatever you decide that process should be. Assuming it works for you (Moodle 2), the Import Powerpoint option in Lesson might be a great option for you. While Word doesn't have a direct "Save As PPT/PPTX" option, if your documents use standard header/outlining styles, Powerpoint can import the outlines. Copy and paste into Powerpoint from Word for the rest of the content after the outline is prepared is tedious but will preserve all your formatting and your "pagination" scheme. I personally don't have any experience with Lesson's Import Powerpoint feature, though. HTH , >L<

ResponsesInList.Title: Lesson complete before continuing course
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a lesson that must be completed before the student can continue to the next task. I have the activity completion set to "student must view this activity to complete it". The problem is that the lesson is several pages. If the student opens the first page and then goes back to the course it shows it completed and allows them to continue. How do I set conditional restrictions to force the student to complete the whole lesson before being able to continue in the coarse? My testing has been unable to accomplish this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson complete before continuing course
ResponsesInList.Text: This is unfortunately not possible in current Moodle versions. This new feature will be available in a few weeks in Moodle 2.9 see https://docs.moodle.org/29/en/Activity_completion_settings#Lesson_completion_settings But if the next activity is also a lesson you can use the prerequisite lesson feature of the lesson activity See https://docs.moodle.org/28/en/Lesson_settings#Prerequisite_lesson Warnings This only works if the next activity is a lesson if lesson A must be completed before lesson B can be attempted, you need to set the prerequisites in lesson B settings This feature will be deprecated in the future, in Moodle 2.9 your lessons with prerequisites will continue to work but you will not be able to create new ones with prerequisites, you will need to use lesson completion settings Lesson prerequisite is an old feature and has known bugs for instance backup and restore may break the prerequisites (this is one reason why I implemented the new completion conditions for Moodle 2.9

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson complete before continuing course
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the information. I will wait for 2.9 instead of upgrading to 2.8.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson complete before continuing course
ResponsesInList.Text: DeWayne, Perhaps you can insert a question page at the end which asks the students a simple question. This should mean that they have to complete the whole lesson and then answer this question before the lesson is marked as complete. Ajmal

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson 2.7 part 2
ResponsesInList.Text: For your first question, see my answer in your other post on the same topic. Is [the "Maximum Number of attempts"] option only active for questions that are graded? Yes, of course. Well, it depends what you call "graded". Graded questions are ALL questions except Essay. Non-graded questions are called Content pages. Sorry if my answers do not sound satisfying, but again the Lesson activity settings are quite complicated to manage, the behaviour of the Lesson can be difficult to understand and the interface needs a serious re-vamping. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 2 columns in my content page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi - easiest way is to add in a table with two columns and one row. You can also then adjust the ratio, eg 30% first column, 70% second column or fix the pixel width of a certain column. If you alter these attributes, after you've created your first table you can just cut and paste the HTML code onto subsequent lesson pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Scoring behaving oddly for numerical question
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a numerical question.  The correct answser is 1/4 with the response of "Correct!  You've successfully completed this lesson." Incorrect answers are 1/5, 1/3, and 1/2 with the incorrect response of "Sorry.  Try again.." However, when I check the question, 1 or 1/ or 1/* are all accepted as correct and I see my response of "Correct!  You've successfully completed this lesson." I have to type in letters such as X or s, etc. to get my incorrect response of "Sorry.  Try again.." Any ideas of what I am doing wrong?  Am I misunderstanding how to use a numerical question? Thanks for any suggestions you may have. Lane in Charlotte, NC

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scoring behaving oddly for numerical question
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lane, Numerical question type is expecting a number (whole or decimal) and not fractions. So instead of 1/5, 1/4, 1/3, and 1/2 use .2, .25, .33, and .5 You can also specify ranges. For example, some users might enter .333 for 1/3. So you could do .33:.334 so that it accepts more numbers. If you want to continue to use fractions though, you can switch to Short answer and it will handle the fractions with no problem. Let me know if this works out for you, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scoring behaving oddly for numerical question
ResponsesInList.Text: Mark,  Thanks!  I haven't had a chance to test your suggestion, but I'm sure it will work.  I will pass it along to the faculty I work with. It would be good if the documentation/help for numerical questions indicated that responses cannot be fractions, etc.  I'll see if I can get this to the right folks.... Thanks also for the quick response. Lane

ResponsesInList.Title: Can you prevent Answers being randomised in Lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all! My lesson author would like to have the possible Answers in the multiple-choice-question-pages in her Lessons presented in the same order each time, instead of randomised. Quizes have a setting called "Shuffle within Questions", which does things like randomise the order in which the possible Answers in a multiple choice are presented to students.  Switching this to "No" makes the Answers appear in the same order each time. Does anyone know how to achieve this effect in Lessons?  How hard is it? With many thanks, Sacha

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can you prevent Answers being randomised in Lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Excellent question. In the past and in the current version, I will say " no". Moodle Lesson 1.8 module does not have the Quiz setting "Shuffle within questions". Thank you for the post, I changed MoodleDocs to answer this relatively common request. Hopefully, we will change it with 1.9. However, a developer will have to tell us if this feature is going to be available in the future. Currently the "new" Question Bank has a shuffle option property associated with individual questions (one multiple choice question's answers can be shuffled, while another multiple choice question's answers are randomized). In 1.8, only the Quiz module uses the Question Bank, but the plan is for any Moodle Module to be able to access this bank. Lesson in 1.8 does not use the Question Bank, and can only import questions that have been exported by Question Bank . The questions I have are: when will the Lesson module use the Question Bank will Lesson have an overall shuffle answer setting (like 1.8 Quiz) and if so, which shuffle setting will rule: the individual question shuffle setting or the overall Lesson setting? Your lesson author will have to wait. Hope this helps Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can you prevent Answers being randomised in Lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, Hi! That's very helpful - thanks for your reply. Sacha

ResponsesInList.Title: Questionnaire in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Does anyone know how to add a questionnaire to a Lesson. That is a set of questions that have neither correct or incorrect answers.  For example "Did you find this lesson interesting?" I would then like to see how many students said "Yes" and how many said "No", as in a normal quiz report, and with no impact on the grades. I have tried using branch tables to do this but I don't get the report data. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Questionnaire in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lester, You can not add a "questionnaire" within the flow of a Lesson. But there is a choice of several modules/ activities which should do what you want, outside of a lesson. If you want your students to answer such questions about a lesson as "Did you find this lesson a) boring; b) OK; c) very interesting, etc." then you could use either the Feedback or the Questionnaire plugin (as a separate activity, to be answered after completing the lesson). Be aware, however, that these are 3rd-party plugins that do not come with standard distributions of Moodle and you'll have to install them on top of your regular installation. The Feedback module will become part of Moodle from (forthcoming) version 2.0. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to force students to watch all videos.

At the moment, I've come up with two options: Option #1 - At the end of the video, have it display (in the video) a number, word , etc.The lesson page that the video is placed in is then set to a question and the student MUST enter the correct answer to proceed (otherwise back to page). ResponsesInList.Title: End of lesson Page - Don't want to show it
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a continuation of the now locked discussion: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=190347 I've been looking into disabling the 'end of lesson page' and instead showing the course page at the end of the lesson. It seems this feature existed previously in Moodle, and could be enabled by going into the Course Settings, and setting Show Gradebook to Student to No. This feature was removed after it was reported as a bug that had escaped detection in Moodle 1 and had been carried through to Moodle 2(all versions), see: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-36877 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=216250 My question is, how can we restore this 'bug/feature' in Moodle 3? so that the 'end of lesson' page can be disabled.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: End of lesson Page - Don't want to show it
ResponsesInList.Text: found the answer in the MDL-36877 patch, a commented out section, if you add the code below to mod/lesson/view.php it will redirect to course page, but only if show grades is off, if show grades is on, then users will see the end of lesson page. I have confirmed that the code modification will work in Moodle 3.2. if (!$course->showgrades) { redirect(new moodle_url('/course/view.php', array('id'=>$course->id))); } I find that turning of the 'end of lesson page' is a convenient feature and improves Moodle's UI, giving students less clicks, and not providing unnecessary ones. A greater improvement would be to make the redirect to another activity be automatic rather than force the user to click a link.

ResponsesInList.Title: Allow access to a Lesson by unaunthenticated users (site visitors)?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am using Moodle 1.9 and created a lesson on the front page that I would like to be usable by anyone visiting the site, without having to log in. But, Moodle seems to always require them to login with at least guest access. I've looked all around, but don't see any option to change this. Any suggestions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Allow access to a Lesson by unaunthenticated users (site visitors)?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andy, That is a site issue, not a Lesson issue. The site can require a person to initially log in (or not) . This is a site admin block>Front page> Front Page setting, at the bottom which says default role, set it for guest. Site Admin block>Security>site policies should also be set so a login is not required. Remember that the Front Page can be treated as a special course. If your site admin says no to that, then put some kind of encouraging welcome on the login splash screen in the right box to encourage guests. Do the same on any page that say "to link to our Moodle for a gander, click here". I would be thinking very hard about the long term implications of placing "course" resources and activities on the front page. For somethings, a Guest course(s) that links from the Front Page, might give more control and flexibility in the long run.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Object Reuse
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jon, You ask a very important question, and what you are trying to do makes a lot of sense. However I would use the term "learning object" with caution. In particular, I would not equate "learning object" to "Moodle activity or resource." A learning object is something more fine-grained than a Moodle activity. It is a small, self-contained chunk, typically 2 to 15 minutes in length, that can be reused in multiple contexts for multiple purposes. The learning objects vision is to have a repository of learning objects tagged with metadata that can be searched by course developers, who can build things like lessons by aggregating learning objects "on-the-fly." In the LMS world, I think the learning objects vision is most closely approximated by SCORM (I'm sure there will be other opinions on this!). Each learning object corresponds to a SCO, SCO's can be aggregated into a SCORM package, and the SCO's can be organized in different ways to produce complete courses or course units (SCORM 1.4 permits very flexible organization). Moodle activities , on the other hand, have an inherently monolithic design. They are self-contained and cannot share content. I do not believe you can use them for what you are trying to do, at least not in a "natural" way.

ResponsesInList.Title: Uploading lesson material across different courses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading lesson material across different courses.
ResponsesInList.Text: I, too, use the same lesson pages in multiple courses.  If there was one change that I wish for in Moodle right now, it would be that Lesson pages could be stored in a "bank", and used in multiple places, like a 'question bank' for quizzes.  The way it is now, if I find an edit is needed, then I have to make the change in many places, and keep track of it all... Enough complaining -- Moodle is still great. It is possible to use the Quiz Module to build something very much like lessons, as long as you don't need the 'branching' functions of the Lesson Mod.  The "Branch Table" page can be replaced by the "Description" in a Quiz.  However, this does NOT work for me because of differences in navigation, and scores being displayed, and several things that I just can't work around.  But you can look at that option... As far as copying Lesson content, you can make duplicates of a Lesson pretty easily.  If you want to copy Lesson-A and change it slightly to become Lesson-B, it goes as follows: 'Backup' Lesson-A Rename Lesson-A to Lesson-B, and change it as necessary 'Restore' Lesson-A from the backup file Hope this helps.  (And I hope sometime Lesson pages can be shared like Quiz questions...) Dan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stop date for Lesson

ResponsesInList.Title: evaluation open question by student himself
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, How can I create an open question (or essay), when filled in by the student, is  directly followed by my answer so the student can evaluate form himself whether he did understand the preceding text. No grading involved. thnx

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: evaluation open question by student himself
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you asking specifically for the Lesson activity or in general how to do this? If you are using the Lesson activity then you can create an Essay question, then create a new content page with your example answer. Go back to the Essay question and set the 'jump' to the name of your example answer page.  Make sure your Lesson settings have the grade as 'Practice lesson' so it is ungraded, and (if you want) allow review and more than one attempt. There are other ways to do this -for example there is an H5P content type called Essay which is worth exploring if you have H5P either as standard in your site or as a plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: evaluation open question by student himself
ResponsesInList.Text: Another possibility is to use the Diary plugin. With it you can even let them revise their entry if you want to.

"True/false" Correct answer score: 0, feedback for correct answer: "Not quite. Would you like to try again?" "Multichoice", "Multichoice - Multiple-answer" and "Short answer" scoring 0, jump "Next Page" (indicating correct answer) feedback for correct answer: " You have answered incorrectly. Would you like to attempt the question again? (If you now answer the question correctly, it will not count towards your final score.) " When the teacher doesn't want to score these but only indicates that the answer is correct and there is feedback as essay, where is only scoring points to the course gradebook, how teacher should create the lesson and it's scoring? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course rating
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Chathuri, Do you want the course rating to be a 'fun only' thing, or do you need to capture and use the results? If it's just for fun, then there is a block your can install (see http://docs.moodle.org/en/Course_rate_block ). This just gives a star rating (out of 5 stars) but does not say how many people have voted. If you want to capture and use the results more fully, then you'll probably need to use the questionnaire ( http://docs.moodle.org/en/Adding/editing_a_questionnaire ) as the results of this will show in Gradebook.

ResponsesInList.Title: quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to figure out how I make the questions mandatory until they get the right answer. I have it set so they have ample attempts, but it currently allows them to get the wrong answer, and then choose to go on, anyway. How do I make it such that they can keep on guessing, but they cannot go on to the next page until they get the right answer?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't. From the Lesson documentation Lesson_settings#Maximum_Number_of_Attempts : Maximum Number of Attempts Decide here how many times you want students to be able to attempt each question. When they reach the maximum, they will be taken automatically to the next page. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: quiz
ResponsesInList.Text:
Joseph, thank you for the straight-forward, purely factual answer. I greatly appreciate your knowledge and assistance.

Still, there is no way to set a minimum number of attempts? I would like to suggest that this system is not so useful if we can't require the students to at least see the correct answer.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Wendi "[...] this system is not so useful if we can't require the students to at least see the correct answer. " If you want the students to see the correct answer to a question, whether they actually found it themselves (through one or more attempts) or not, then you could put that answer at the start of the text of the next page that the students will navigate to. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: That's a great idea, Joseph. Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Feature request -- default navigation, defaults in general
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not sure if this is the place for feature requests, but I wanted to suggest two features for the Lesson module. 1.) I have found that I want all of my Lessons in a single course (or all of my courses, actually) to behave in the same fashion, and that it's a bit annoying to have to make sure that each Lesson has the same checks and YESs and Nos. I would rather go to one place that governs how all of the Lessons in that course operate. If you want to change one particular Lesson, then the settings in that individual Lesson could take precedence over the course level settings. 2.) Related to that, it seems like it would not be hard to create defaults for the Navigation. I've found that 95% of the time I want simple "Previous" and "Next" buttons for my Lesson pages (with just the "Next" on the first page). It seems like it would be nice to have a set of options in the Lesson settings for the text and relative pointers for those navigation buttons (So you could make yours all say "Retreat!" and "Onward!" if you want.) Then, when you're adding each page in turn, it would give you the same options as it does now, just with a checkbox that says "Use defaults" that you would uncheck before adding your own boxes, or adding other branches or whatever. Or it automatically knows that when you put text in those boxes, the defaults are not used... Anyway, just my two cents. If there's another place for feature requests, I'll put this there, instead.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feature request -- default navigation, defaults in general
ResponsesInList.Text: Note that Moodle 2.1 has the feature that you can duplicate any activity. So you can make a 'Template lesson' with the basic settings you want, hide it from students, and then keep copying it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feature request -- default navigation, defaults in general
ResponsesInList.Text: I did not know that! We're on 2.0.3...which seems to be the most up to date version you can download here. You say "has," indicating it exists somewhere! Is this a development build? I do like the sound of that feature, though it has that standard "built-in-workaround" flavor that I've learned to expect from Moodle. Only for the usage I'm talking about here, though. There have been plenty of other cases where I've wanted to duplicate an activity (a long lesson that you want to split into two, for instance) that will now be easier...in 2.1, apparently! Thanks for your response, Tim.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feature request -- default navigation, defaults in general
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 2.1 has been in beta testing for some weeks now. With a fair wind, it should be released tomorrow.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 2.2 Including flash in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have a few lectures packaged in flash that I want to include as part of a lesson in Moodle. I've uploaded the .swf file but it does not open and play when you access the lesson page. Is there a player to be installed? Can it be done at all? Thanks, Manuel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.2 Including flash in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello You need an <iFrame> tage inserting around your .swf file (in html mode). Here's an earlier post where I helped someone else with the iFrame code for a shockwave flash object: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=194959&parent=849432

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.2 Including flash in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lynn, Thanks for the really quick reply! I see the idea is to include: <iframe width="#" align="middle" scrolling="0" height="#" frameborder="0" src="http://yourdomain/Yourswf.swf"></iframe> my question (forgive my ignorance) is where? Thanks again! Manuel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.2 Including flash in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Ok... as you want this in a lesson, it needs to go within a lesson page. You must put this into the page in HTML mode (click the <> sign to switch from the wysiwyg view). You can dump this code into a blank page, then the swf will be the only thing on that page. (For instance, in theory your lesson could be one page in length with just this swf on it - although I'd recommened doing something else in that case, like just putting the swf into a single web page instead, but you get the idea). Equally, you can put it into a page with other things already in it - there could be an intro paragraph that you want peope to read before they view the swf. In this case, put in all your other inclusions (text, images, whatever) then switch to HTML view and paste in the code (with your file name changes) into wherever you need it within the page. The iFrame and the swf object itself will not conflict with any other text, images or other object (eg a youTube clip) so it will fit in easily. I'm not on my own computer so I can't do a screen grab for you at the moment to show what the outcome is. If you still can't get this working, post back and I'll help further. Hope this helps?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.2 Including flash in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey Lynn, Great! It works like a charm! Thanks so much for your help! Manuel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Results to multiple choice question not showing
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jackie, I am sort of the resident New User. I am just getting back into gear after a wonderful vacation (all too short) in Firenze. The gateway detail was interesting. I also would first point my finger at the clusters and then double check my update lesson settings. There could be a bug in the 1.7 lesson code you are using but I would not take any bets on that. You said it usually did not reach the first question. The first question is a numeric question that is placed before the cluster start in the "logical order" (teacher edit view mode order). This would indicate lesson setting flow control issue, not a cluster issue. But something might have gotten lost in the transcription to this forum, so here is more info. I would get my hands dirty and delete every cluster and end of cluster page in the lesson. Does it still jump around when you use a student login? Works fine, then See MoodleDocs on clusters . If it still acts weird then you probably have a lesson setting (check flow control area again) problem. See MoodleDocs on Flow Control and Lesson settings . My golden rule, "crawl, walk, run". Create a straight line mini lesson. KISS. Don't invest a lot of energy in it. 10 pages, start with a couple of branch pages, don't put in any jumps or descriptions. Put in MC or T/F questions , with "right", "wrong", "real wrong", "wild". Don't bother with custom scoring. Wrong answers stay on this page, the correct answer is always the first one and it goes to next page. End with a couple of branch pages. You should advance right through the lesson. Then do a backup of the lesson. Next throw in a start cluster and end cluster. If that does not work, email me (see my profile) a copy of a backup of your lesson, without students. I will throw it into one of my localhosts and give it a look. You don't appear to be doing anything complicated. It has to be something simple like you suspect. Best Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Bug #4174 - Lesson Essay Question Can't be Graded
ResponsesInList.Text:
I have entered this into the bug tracker... In the lesson module, a teacher will get the error "Error: could not
find grades" if they try to mark a lesson essay before the student has
completed the lesson. When the teacher goes to the lesson screen, they will see that there is
an essay to mark even if the student hasn't completed the lesson. If
they try to mark the essay, they will get that error. The problem stems
from the code trying to 'update' the grade record. Because the student
hasn't completed the rest of the lesson, the record doesn't exist yet,
and generates the error. To fix it, either the lesson should not allow the essay to be marked
until after the lesson has been completed, or it should create a grade
record if one doesn't exist. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bug #4174 - Lesson Essay Question Can't be Graded
ResponsesInList.Text:
Thanks for finding this. the lesson should not allow the essay to be marked
until after the lesson has been completed This would be the best solution.  Creating a grade record could potentially break several things.

ResponsesInList.Title: Multichoice - Multiple-answer
ResponsesInList.Text: So my understanding of this feature is... there are answers A, B and C. say the actual answer is A and C. A and C have to have identical feedback. B's feedback will have a "wrong" feedback for it. So if anything is chosen other than the combo of A and C, B's feedback will show up. What if the answer is A, B and C though? Where would I put "incorrect" feedback? thanks, Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multichoice - Multiple-answer
ResponsesInList.Text: See my example below. Lesson MCQ with multiple answers option: Which of the following are animals? Multiple Choice - Multianswer Answer 1:     the cat Response 1:     yes, the cat and the dog are animals Score 1:     1 Jump 1:     Next page Answer 2:     the dog Response 2: Score 2:     1 Jump 2:     Next page Answer 3:     the tulip Response 3:     Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... Score 3:     0 Sample student answers: the cat, the dog -> yes, the cat and the dog are animals the cat -> Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... the dog -> Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... the rose -> Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... the cat, the rose -> Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... the dog, the rose -> Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... the rose, the tulip -> Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... the cat, the dog, the rose -> Your answer is incomplete or contains wrong choices... etc. There can only be two possible feedback messages for this type of question: one for the full correct answer and one for any other answer (incomplete or wrong). When creating the question, the correct feedback message must be entered in the "Response" field of the very first correct Answer field, the incorrect feedback message must be entered in the "Response" field of the very first incorrect Answer field, all the other Response fields can/should be left empty, since they will not be used. I hope that makes things clear. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multichoice - Multiple-answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Joseph. So to be clear, if all the answers are correct, there is no way of providing feedback if they don't get them all? Thanks, Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multichoice - Multiple-answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Andrew " ... if all the answers are correct, there is no way of providing feedback if they don't get them all? " Sorry, I do not understand what you mean. Please provide an example. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multichoice - Multiple-answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joseph, So... Which of the following are body parts? * arm * leg * nose So all are correct. So in order to progress all have to be ticked. So how do we provide feedback in this case which says that "sorry you've missed something out"? There is no incorrect answer to write that feedback in with. Because from what I understand, the same feedback e.g. "great you got all 3" will be the feedback for all 3 answers above. thanks, Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multichoice - Multiple-answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Andrew, thanks for clearing things up! Your question poses 2 problems to me: one technical (easily resolved) and one pedagogical. 1.- In the current Lesson questions editing interface - for the case at hand - there is indeed no way to enter a specific feedback message for a wrong choice, since there are no wrong choices! One workaround, however, is to set your whole Lesson to use "Default feedback": Flow control -> Display default feedback YES . Here is the online Help for that Display default feedback setting: If set to Yes , then when a response is not found for a particular question, the default response of "That's the correct answer" and "That's the wrong answer" will be used. If set to No , then when a response is not found for a particular question, then no feedback is displayed. The user taking the Lesson will automatically be directed to the next Lesson page. 2. On the pedagogical level or, more specifically on the linguistic level, the wording of your question "Which of the following are body parts?" presupposes that not all proposed choices are correct, only some of them . From a pedagogical perspective, I would say that asking such a question and expecting all of the choices to be selected is like "playing a trick" on the students. Hope that helps, Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: e+Learning vs. e-Learning
ResponsesInList.Text: Modelling of e-Learning Processes: an Approach Used in Plovdiv e-University George Totkov, Elena Somova, Mariana Sokolova Abstract: Most of the e-Learning systems don’t have means for modelling a learning process and in particular the structure and content of the virtual learning courses. In PeU learning environment virtual courses are designed by using directed graph with nodes of two types: informative (learning materials or groups of them – AND, OR, MORE etc.) and controlling (Join_Split, Repeat, Check_Point, etc. ). For the development and editing of courses in PeU, the authors use environment with visual programming elements.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: e+Learning vs. e-Learning
ResponsesInList.Text: BEST: New Lessons Module Logic Daniel Denev, Rositsa Doneva, George Totkov Abstract : Most of the known e -Learning environments do not have means for modelling the structure of the learning lessons, i.e. for representing the logical order in which the concepts are presented to the learners. In this direction, in the frame of the BEST project, a research for extending the functionality of the Moodle concept "Lesson module" is carried out. The paper presents the basic ideas and results of the research. The BEST project for development of a virtual learning environment focuses on didactic approach to e-learning . It is based on the following principles: learning is a goal-directed process (teachers have opportunity to define the lesson logics on the basis of its learning objectives and the possibility to monitor and measure the quality of the learning process); learning is embedded in a conceptual context , etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: e+Learning vs. e-Learning
ResponsesInList.Text: Content Management in e-Learning vs. Learning Design in e -Learning e-Learning has a well developed approach to the creation and sequencing of content-based, single learner, self-paced learning objects. However, there is little understanding of how to create sequences of learning activities wh ich involve groups of learners interacting within a structured set of collaborative environments, or how teachers can make these sequences easily re-usable (making national fund of re-usable learning sequences). Given that a key dimension of Bulgarian higher education is learning which arises from interacting with teachers and peers (rather than simply interacting with content), the lack of a mature approach to sequencing of multi-learner activities is a significant blind spot in e-Learning today. This is surprising given that "lesson planning" – the process of determining the sequence of activities to be followed by a lecturer and learners when studying a topic – is well understood in education, but is mainly absent from e -Learning. However, there is a growing body of work addressing this topic, based on the concept of "Learning Design". Learning Design provides a first glimpse at the ways of describing multilearner activity sequences and the tools required to support these. Learning Design has the potentia l to revolutionize e-Learning by capturing the "process" of education, rather than simply content management as it in Moodle. By describing sequences of collaborative learning processes in Bulgarian universities, Learning Design offers new pedagogical approaches to re -use in e-Learning. This article describes our joint Learning Design approach, a detailed example, and its implementation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: flashcards in a part of a lesson
ResponsesInList.Text:
Flashcards would randomize the whole lesson.  In lesson 1.5 you can wrap questions in a Cluster page and an End of Cluster page to create randomization. So, set up your lesson as follows: Intro pages... Cluster Question Page 1 Question Page 2 Question Page ... End of Cluster End of the Lesson or More Pages This way the student sees the intro pages, then hits the cluster and all the question pages are random (or like flashcard).  Also, all questions within the cluster should jumpto "This page" or "
Unseen question within a cluster".  Do this if you want to hit all the questions in the cluster.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 2.0 - Moving Questions between lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: How do I export questions from one lesson in a course to another in the same course?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 - Moving Questions between lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sue In the absence of a reply from any of the real experts here, I think I can safely say that unfortuntaely you can't. The questions in a Lesson cant be imported from any Question Bank questions you might have created (wish they could!!), they have to be created afresh for each Lesson. The only possible workaround is to "duplicate" the existing Lesson and use the duplicate as the basis for the new lesson in which you want the questions. But that will only work if youre drawing the questions from a single Lesson, since you cannot merge Lessons either. To "duplicate" say, Lesson X in Course Y, you need to have another (real or dummy course), Z, into which you import Lesson X, and then re-import the Lesson back to Course Y. The other (not really an) alternative is to use the Quiz module to deliver the questions, in which case you have the freedom to use the Question Bank. But of course that means students are chopping and changing from Lesson to Quiz. (Off topic: Clumsy, ay? It always stuns me that what seems to be the most used Module in the world's leading Course MS is so woefully inadequate!) Good luck! Geoff

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 - Moving Questions between lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: Geoff is right, there is no possibility to export question pages from the Lesson activity. It is however possible to import questions from the Quiz questions bank into a Lesson. I expect the lack of that export/import feature can be explained by the very nature of Moodle's Lesson activity, which is fundamentally different from the Quiz activity. In a Moodle Lesson, the flow of Question pages is controlled by the student's answers or choices. This means that in "normal" use (if there is such a thing as "normal" in this context ), each question derives part of its meaning from its immediate context: the question(s) preceding and the question(s) following it. When you keep this in mind, it would ("usually") not make much sense to draw questions from a bank, in order to import them into a Lesson activity. It would be interesting to hear from the original poster why precisely she needs to "move" questions from one Lesson to another. And to specify how she would "link" those questions one with the other in the new Lesson. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 - Moving Questions between lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm unsure I'm understanding you, Joseph. When a student answers a question, his/her answer con only be 1) Correct, 2) Partially correct and 3) Wrong. With this in mind, lesson flow logic can make appropiate decisions to take student to one page or another, and those decisions are independent of question contents. I mean question logic can be (ant ought to be) separated from lesson flow logic. In this way teachers should be able to move questions around, and have a question bank, to reuse questions between various activities , not just quizzes. In fact I vaguely remember reading some time ago that for Moodle 2.0 rewritting question code completely was planned to separate its code from quizzes, rendering code more "orthogonal", to allow question usage in various parts of Moodle, a feature I think is still not possible. Am I wrong?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 - Moving Questions between lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: @Orestes and Geoff (and OP ) Of course in my previous post I was being a bit "dogmatic" about the "normal" use of the Lesson activity. However, I tend to disagree with Orestes that " question logic can be (ant ought to be) separated from lesson flow logic ". In my pedagogy, a Lesson (and a Quiz) need to be constructed with relevant questions which follow one upon another, and certainly not questions chosen "at random". That's why I have no use for the "random questions" feature of the Quiz activity, for example. Of course I'll have to admit that there are other views in this matter. @Orestes: The feature you are alluding to has cropped up from time to time over the years in these forums but nothing has come out of it.  For quite a few years, unfortunately, the Lesson module no longer has an active maintainer, unlike the Quiz module, where Tim Hunt is very active. The Lesson module is almost an "orphan" in the Moodle development strategy - at the moment. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 - Moving Questions between lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: Joseph, that's one interesting issue because very often I use the same lesson in another course with different students. So, we have to adapt the lesson to the new "class". lesson's should have a menu similar to the quiz, because we can mix the parts in another adapted way. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 - Moving Questions between lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Geoff, You are right, in the Lesson activity there is no option to directly import questions from the questions bank. The indirect procedure is as follows: In the Questions bank, group into one category all the questions you want to use in one Lesson activity. Export that category of questions (Moodle XML format) and save that XML file. Go the the Lesson where you need those questions. (Moodle 1.9) On the Edit lesson page, select Expanded view. Click on the Import questions link at the place where you want to insert questions. On your computer, select the XML file you previously exported from the questions bank. That's it!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 2.8.3  How do I make the titles of the lessons look bigger?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Wendi, It looks like there are 2 things you want to change: In terms of changing the size of the text: To shrink the availability info, I think you want to add the following CSS to your theme: .availabilityinfo {font-size:10pt} .availabilityinfo strong {font-weight:normal} To enlarge the activity name, I think you want to add the following CSS to your theme: .instancename {font-size:16pt;} These changes can either be done through the admin settings (assuming your theme supports it) by navigating to Site Administration -> Appearance ->Themes -> (Your theme name) and adding the above CSS to the customcss field.  If your theme does not support adding custom CSS from the admin interface, then you will need to add it to one of the stylesheets  that make up your theme.  You should be able to find them in /theme/yourthemename/style/ folder on your moodle servers hard drive. In terms of changing the text to say: Not available unless "Lesson 1” is marked
complete you want to look at the Language customization tool located at: Site Administration -> Language ->Language Customization. The string you want to edit is located in the "availability_completion" file and the string you most likely want to edit is called "requires_complete"

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson grade won't show 0
ResponsesInList.Text: Alice, I'm not sure yours and Mike's problem are related. It is not clear what you mean by "[my students] did not "complete" the lesson. Do you mean they have not reached the end of the lesson? Or that they have reached the end of the lesson but do not receive a grade? It is perfectly normal for a lesson to have "optional" pages which can never be visited by the students. The important thing for a student to get a grade upon completing a lesson is that at least one page they visited has a graded question page on it . If your lessson consists only or mostly of branch pages, i.e. pages with no real question on it (multiple choice, etc.), then, even if the student "completes" the lesson, i.e. reaches the end of it, it will not be graded. Please tell us if that is the case with your lesson (and I'll suggest a workaround). I think this matter has already been mentioned on this Lesson forum. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change wording of "Congrats" screen at the end of lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: What version are you using? I'm not sure when it started (1.9?) but it's possible to edit most language files via the front page Site Administration block. From the front page Site Administration block go to Language → Language editing → edit words or phrases → lesson.php , from the dropdown menu. Then do a search (CTRL+F) on "congratulations". Edit to taste. Save. If you don't have that option (pre-1.9?), then you'll need to go to your server and find the lang/en_utf8/lesson.php file, open in a text editor, do a search for "congratulations". Edit to taste. Save. Upload to server.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change wording of "Congrats" screen at the end of lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kameron, In the language pack your site is using. See Language editing and then the lesson.php file. You will need to be able to have the right permissions because this impacts the whole Moodle site. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Online Question after lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Sorry for the delay in answering your post. The Quiz module will do what you want. Use the Quiz settings so that 1 question appears on a page at a time and that it is pulling random questions from a question category. This is what I am seeing on your link that uses html pages. The Lesson module is always set up so that there is one button to submit the answer on a single page. Based upon the answer the student selected and the jump the teacher set, the student will go to the page the teacher wants. For example, in a question about color hue, all the wrong answers might gets a different response, then go to a branch table page that gives more information about color hue. On this page, one of the buttons at the bottom might send the student back for another unseen question in a cluster, and another to the end of lesson where the student sees their grade.

ResponsesInList.Title: Structure of Lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: I am new and trying to understand the structure of lessons.  It appears that the hierarchy is: Course Topic Lesson Other Resources and activities Once I have created a lesson, can I move it to a different topic? It would be more intuitive for me if I could create lessons outside of courses, and include the created lesson in any topic of any course.  Same with resources.  Is this capability available and I am just missing it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Structure of Lessons
ResponsesInList.Text: Moving Lessons: Yes. With editing turned on, click on the up/down arrows in the row of icons to the right of the Lesson's name link. Then click on the rectangle with a dashed border in the location to which you want it moved. Whole topic sections may be moved by clicking the arrow(s) to the right in the array of icons. Backup / Restore: You can create course items with any module inc. Resource, back it up and restore it to any course. So you could create your Lessons, say, in a devt course back them up for later resore in any other course. The backup/restore functions are accessed from the Administration block on the course page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Lessons not registering as completed
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm a bit of a noob with Moodle, but I've run into the first problem I can't figure out by myself. I have a course that is a series of lessons that need to be taken sequentially. Most of these lessons are straight branch tables that the user reads and clicks through before being allowed to take the next lesson. Lesson 2, 3, 4 etc has a dependency set up on contingency of completing the previous lesson. The problem I'm having, is that I can't ever seem to "complete" lessons that are just straight branch tables. Logging in as a student, I click through each lesson, the progress bar thinks it's complete, I get the "congratulations - end of lesson reached" message but when I try to select the next lesson (which has a dependency on the previous) it gives an error saying I must complete the lesson just completed before proceeding. These links are to a screen capture of the:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lessons not registering as completed
ResponsesInList.Text: Matt We are just feeling our way through Moodle as well with setting up our course.  For some reason, if you just click through all the lesson pages as Continue the lesosn doesn't register it as complete. I had the same problem but ended up doing the following; I just added one more question page and put a selection (i.e. answer) for them to select which simply got them to 'check' the answer Lesson Completed . This seems to have solved the problem and not the system recognises the lesson as completed. e.g I put in the following on the last Question Page Check the Lesson Completed button if you have read through all lesson material and are ready to attempt the assignment.  Otherwise use the navigation buttons on your browser to review lesson. Then I created on answer which simply required them to check the answer Lesson Completed Don't know if that is the right way to fix the problem , but worked for me

ResponsesInList.Title: Lesson Problem: Chemistry-related
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmmm... This is from one of our chemistry teachers. I really do not know what to tell him. Suggestions appreciated! -- Art Art: As promised, a summary of the MOODLE session with my CP kids today. I had the students working through the 2 tutorials on nomenclature in my Help Lessons course.  I had only checked navigation on the WRITING FORMULAS FROM NAMES lesson, and I had to make some changes before the kids went into the attack.  I didn't see, until after we had started, that the other lesson, NAMING COMPOUNDS AND ACIDS, had similar mine fields in it. The system would not accept parentheses.  If the correct formula was iron(III) nitrate, it would only accept ironIII nitrate as correct.  If the students included the (), it rejected the answer.  If the correct answer was Mg(OH)2, it would only accept MgOH2.  I can accept that we cannot write subscripts in the answers.  No problem.  But leaving out the () makes a whole different animal. I also noticed two other problems.  The system did not appear to be case-sensitive, which is bad.  If the correct formula was KMnO4, it would accept KMNO4.  This is very different.  Mn is manganese, while MN is an element which, if you discovered it, would get you a Nobel prize.  (N is nitrogen, and there is no element M.)  It also refused to accept one correct answer in the Naming Compounds lesson.  The formula H2CO3 is carbonic acid, which I entered for the short-answer response.  When I typed carbonic acid in the answer space, it rejected it.  And I thought it was supposed to give up after 5 tries.  This one just kept kicking me back to the question.  There was no escape.  I was doomed! AAAAAAHHHHHGGGGHHHHHH !!!  (Sorry.  I got carried away.)  Anyway, any light you can shed on this would help.  I think I can work around some of it, but it would be nice if I didn't have to. Thanks, Dave ChemMaster Smith

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson Problem: Chemistry-related
ResponsesInList.Text: Would escaping the parens in the answer in some way be possible? Thanks, Art

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson Problem: Chemistry-related
ResponsesInList.Text: He needs to check the 'case-sensitive' box on short-answer questions that accept chemical formulas. I haven't seen the parenthesis problem in lessons- I know parentheses are fine in short-answer questions in quizzes.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson essay questions - way to force submit?
ResponsesInList.Text: Erin "The way we have lessons set up, students never reach the "end of lesson" page," Well, that is the source of your problem. Try to set up your lessons differently.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson essay questions - way to force submit?
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, the client preferred learners not see the end of lesson page, but in order for them to also use essays, we had to adjust lesson navigation. For anyone reading this later on with similar questions or client concerns about how that page looks, we did discover we could make the end of lesson page more palatable to the client by adjusting some of the CSS , and also by removing a lot of the text on the end of lesson page via language customization. (using to have the text disappear).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson essay questions - way to force submit?
ResponsesInList.Text: Set up the next activity to be dependent on the completion of the lesson. And in the lesson, set up "The student must reach the end of the lesson to complete".

ResponsesInList.Title: Tiered Grading in the Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: I have posted to the Moodle tracker. If you think this would be a good feature please add your vote to it so that we might be able to find some way of getting it implemented. If you have a solution to this I would love to hear it. Thanks Tom ---------- The lesson is one of the most powerful tools in Moodle, and in my training I hear some great ideas. While I know that using only content pages does not register or record a score or grade for completing it, someone suggested a scenario where they would like the final page of a lesson (without having to use a quiz in the lesson) to return a score for the ending up at the decision they had. The example was for students making decisions on medical issues, and having a few out comes to the path they take. For instance the student may go down path "A" which is following the correct procedure so they would finally score 100%. However if they make a mistake at one point and end up at result "B" they are still providing the correct and same out come as "A" but actually have got the right result almost by accident so would score 50%, then a final incorrect path would score 0%. A tiered grading system depending on your decisions but without having to build in question pages, as the learning is more about why they make the choices than testing the book learned knowledge.

If the answer option is Organism*, and the student enters Organisms, no feedback appears. If the answer option is Vegetation, and the student enters Vegetation, feedback appears. If the answer option is Vegetation, and the student enters vegetation, no feedback appears. Does anyone have any answers that will make this work properly (and ignore case)? Multichoice Answer 1 : the bus Response 1 wrong answer Score 0 Jump This page Answer 2 : the cat Response 2 correct! Score 1 Jump Next page Answer 3 : the computer Response 3 no way! Score 0 Jump This page

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable the  display for anwser list order on true/False question
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello William, To do this you need to comment or delete the 2 lines 
```text
shuffle($answers);
```
 in the mod/lesson/pagetypes/truefalse.php file. Note that my advice is  NOT to do that if you want to use lesson grades to evaluate students as it makes cheating somewhat more easy. But if you only use lessons for learning that's OK.

ResponsesInList.Title: Progress Bar Behavior
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently, the progress bar calculates a completion percentage based on the total number of pages in the lesson. If the user restarts the lesson, the progress bar doesn't reset. In other words, once I view all the pages, the progress bar will always be completely green. In some cases, this is the desired behavior. In other cases, we want one of the following instead: Progress bar represents the position of the current page within the lesson, rather than a completion percentage. For example, page 2 of 10, rather than 20%. Resetting the progress bar isn't an issue in this case. Progress bar represents a completion percentage, but it resets when the user restarts the lesson. This may not be as important, because in this case, what we really want is probably the position, not the percentage. Are either of these possible without custom code? Ideally, the behavior of the progress bar would be configurable within the UI. Instead of just turning it on or off, the course designer would specify its behavior. In the meantime, can an admin configure it, either at the course or site level? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Grading
ResponsesInList.Text: I have several lessons consisting of a simple linear flow; info page followed by question page, followed by branch, followed by info followed by question page and so on. I have set the following parameters: Allow student review: Yes Display review button: Yes Maximum number of attempts: 5 Minimum number of questions: 9 (there are 9 questions in the lesson in total) Display left menu: yes and only display if Student has grade greater than 70% There are options to "End Lesson" throughout. My question/problem is that if the student only tries 1 question, gets it correct and then "Ends Lesson" the grade is shown as 100% instead of 1/9 I'm sure it's because I'm not understanding how the grading works or is it something to do with the "End Lesson" ? I would have thought with the parameters above whatever happens the grade should not be more than 1/9?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dave, The grading for lesson is rather tricky because it is possible that a user could answer any number of questions and skip any number due to branching and jumps. So, lesson looks at what the user actually attempted, scores those, and then scales it to the max grade setting. I believe this is for when Custom scoring is turned On. I think what you are looking for is when Custom Scoring is turned Off. With this setting turned Off, each question answered correctly equates to 1 and then the minimum number of questions attempted can be enforced. Hope this helps, cheers, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mark: I've set custom scoring to off but now another problem. Even if the question is answered incorrectly the "scoring" says that the question has actually been answered correctly and the grade goes up. Here's the message after question 1 has been answered incorrectly: Number of questions answered: 1; (You should answer at least: 14) Number of correct answers: 1 Your current grade is 7.1 out of 100 (that didn't happen with custom scoring on: although I had my initial problem if a question was answered incorrectly the grade/score did not increase.) Now I'm really confused.As always any help more than appreciated Dave

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dave, When custom scoring is turned Off, then correct/incorrect answers are determined by the jump. So if an answer jumps to this page or backwards in the navigational flow of the lesson, then it is incorrect. If the jump goes forward in the navigational flow of the lesson, then it is correct. I think this is what you are grappling with now. Cheers, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mark, that's very helpful. I'm going to spend some time this week on trying to unravel the mystique of the lesson marking system. When I'm finished I'll post a resume! Many thanks indeed for your interest and help Dave

These are special navigation pages in Lesson. Are you using any of these special pages in your lesson? And of course, which version of Moodle are you using. Best Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: not going to next question after max number attempts

ResponsesInList.Title: Lesson Settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Student Complaint: They enter essays into a lesson block, but their essays don't seem to get entered. What are the settings for partial lesson completion, so that the can come back and finish a lesson later? How can a teacher get to the lesson essays easy, to comment on them?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson Settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is the issue. For some reason, Moodle likes multiple choice items, short answer items, and matching items because there is an answer and a real point value assigned to the answer and it is checked. Essays are not checked until the instructor marks them. That seems to be where Moodle get confused and doesn't "mark" the part of the lesson the student is on when they exit. If you have a lesson where there are multiple choice items after the essay questions and the student makes it to the multiple choice portion, then Moodle "marks" the lesson and saves where the student left off. Currently from my investigation there isn't a fix for this problem. I have created a workaround for this and shared it on a forum here on Moodle, I just can't remember where. I also shared this on the Oakland Schools website. I will duplicate my workaround for you here, and hopefully it will work for you, it has worked quite well for my students.

Thanks for any help you can provide. BJ

ResponsesInList.Title: Multi-Answer / Multi-Choice
ResponsesInList.Text: Our lessons have several multi-choice / multi-answer questions throughout. We use activity locks /completion check marks for each module/lesson. I wondered if anyone had input regarding a situation where a student checks the two correct answers, in addition to an incorrect one. The results are: The student is able to progress to the next question as if it was completely correct. At the end of the lesson, 11.11% is taken off the score for the incorrect answer in the multi-answer question. Consequently, since the activity locks were set, the student was unable to progress to the next lesson, or return to the completed one as the green check mark is only activated after a complete score of 100%. The scoring on all muli-choice / multi-answer questions are set to jump to the "next page" on correct answers, and stay on "this page" for incorrect answers (earn 1 point for correct answers). I changed the scoring setting for the second attempt to be "maximum" not "mean" so eventually they were able to progress...Not an ideal set up though as the student was able to progress with an incorrect answer, not knowing which one they got wrong. Is there a way to change the settings to ensure against this happening again? I am not sure how to ignore the incorrect answers and to avoid a negative score.I bet there is a simple solution. Thanks.  I have enjoyed learning how to use Moodle.  It is a lovely program! Aly

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multi-Answer / Multi-Choice
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Aly, One solution might be that you will need to increase the Maximum number of attempts in the Lesson settings.  If this setting is set to one, then the student will only get one attempt at answering the question and if s/he answers incorrectly and the jump is "this page" then s/he moves to the next page. Hope this helps, Mark

ResponsesInList.Text: Mark, I have each lesson set to a high number of attempts x7.  The problem seems to be when s/he selects all correct answers in the multi answer in addition to an incorrect one.  It will jump them to the next page not indicating that it is incorrect. % is taken off the incorrect answer for overall score on lesson. Thanks for your help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multi-Answer / Multi-Choice

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multi-Answer / Multi-Choice

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: KEEP HTML VISIBLE and PLAY MP3

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: KEEP HTML VISIBLE and PLAY MP3
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. First of all, I haven't "referenced" anything or done anything complex - you talk about an HTML file. Is this a file you have created and uploaded yourself? I don't use that - if I want a sound file to play in a webpage I turn on the editing, type a few blank spaces, select/highlight them and  select "add a resource>compose a webpage" (if I am in 1.9 or else "page" if I am in 2.0 ) and then I type in a few blank spaces, click the link/chain icon and then upload my mp3 file at that moment. If I have already uploaded it then I need to paste its URL into the URL box that comes up when I click the insert link icon. When I save this, a blue line will appear - but when I have saved the page itself , the sound file will appear in a player as mine did above. If you are using an external HTML file that you have uploaded, as opposed to Moodle's inbuilt "webpage" then I can't help you - but anywhere that you have the text editor - so, label, topic summary, webpage and indeed, forum like here, if you have multimediat plugins enabled, then you can link to and display a sound file or video in its player
