ResponsesInList.Title: Course related problem
ResponsesInList.Text: is it possible that when we create a quiz on another system it will automatically come in moodle, is there any plug-in avilable. pls help me

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course related problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, What does "create quiz on another system" mean? Which system? It if is another Moodle system that is roughly the same version you don't need a plug in, there are too many ways to bring in a quiz and/or its questions. You could use a backup process in one Moodle site/course and then restore it to your course. Within a same Moodle site, there is the Import function, where you can import any activity from another course you teach. It is possible to create a file with questions from a question category in Moodle, save that and import that into another site. I would be looking at MoodleDocs , Quiz module , Question bank especially the Import questions and Export questions links. It is possible to export questions from question bank in a file type, then import/insert that file into a lesson. See Adding a question page and the import question section. Hope this helps Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson DataBase IDs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eduardo, The id number you can see in the browser, e.g. http://moodle/mod/ lesson /view.php?id=869 is not the lesson id. It is the id of the course module . You will need to use the moodle database table mdl_course_modules table to find it. As far as I can see, the lesson id is not used anywhere in the lesson files. You might like to have a look at file mod/lesson/locallib.php, function lesson_get_basics($cmid = 0, $lessonid = 0) {}. You will see that this function is never called with the 2 parameters, but always with one parameter (the $cmid). Hope that helps, Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson module, is this how it is intended to behave?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Benoit, I don't understand that you don't understand the Lesson behaviour.😟 It's very clear: You have seen more than one page of this lesson already. Do you want to start from the last page you viewed? " If the user selects "Yes," they are redirected back to a question they have already completed and are required to answer it again . The Lesson only remembers the last page viewed by the student, whether that page contains just text or a question. If that last viewed page contains a question, the Lesson has not kept the student's answer in memory, so it's logical that they are required to answer it "again".

ResponsesInList.Title: Measuring "Time spent" in Lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Further to these discussions Prerequisite Lesson vs Conditional activities and the second question asked by Wendi in that other discussion: Timer . 1.- Like the Quiz activity, the Lesson activity features a timer. This is used to limit the time spent in a Lesson to a certain number of minutes. The Lesson timer is not as sophisticated as the Quiz timer, as it will only refresh upon student submit action. 2.- In a Lesson's prerequisite features, a lesson (B) can be set to be made available to a student only spent a required number of minutes in another lesson (A). However, there is nothing to tell a student how much time they have spent in a lesson so far (while taking the lesson) nor how much time they have spent in a lesson (when they have reached the end of the lesson). In order to avoid confusion with the original Timer feature, I suggest this would called "Stop watch" or "Chronometer". I agree with Wendi's suggestion that such a feature would be useful in this case. This might be a similar "widget" to the so-called "Progress bar". Each time a student has submitted an answer/changed pages, a message could be displayed along these lines: "You have already spent xx minutes in this lesson (A). You need to spend a minimum of yy minutes here in order to access Lesson B." A more sophisticated feature might even display a progress bar showing the target time and time spent, similar to the progress bar. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Text: So, I take it that nothing like this has been developed yet?

The notes in the file say that it originally had a clock, and then it was modified to be a countdown timer. Is there a way to modify this code and bring back the clock, make it a "count up" timer that is in synch with the prerequisite command of time spent in lesson A before being allowed access to lesson B?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Congratulations end of lesson reached
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frances, This is not a Lesson problem, but a more general problem of "how to edit the moodle language strings". Please see the documentation for Language editing . Note it's different in moodle 1.9.x and moodle 2.0. The language string you'll want to edit is in the Lesson module (of course), and it's called 'congratulations'. Hope that helps, Joseph PS.- Do not edit moodle's core files if all you want is to change a language string. The correct way to go is Edit language files, through the moodle interface.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Congratulations end of lesson reached
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your reply Joseph. That language editing doc is not quite accurate for me so I'll put my method here in case anyone with the same problems stumbles across this post. My problem was I do not have a Language Editing option as the doc says.  I had to go to Site Administration > Language > Language Customization . I then got a dropdown menu with English as the only option.  After selecting that I got a button that says Check out String into Translator.  Pressing that brought up "Strings checked out successfully into the translator" and a green bar with a continue button underneath.  Clicking that brings up the option to  find and alter strings.  The one I wanted was under Mod, lesson.php as Joseph said.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Congratulations end of lesson reached
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frances. The link Joseph gave you linked back to the old Moodle 1.9 Language editing (even though it says 2.0 - the docs are in the process of being updated) As you correctly found out it is now called Language Customisation and the new link is here http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Language_customization

ResponsesInList.Title: alternate method for editing lesson pages
ResponsesInList.Text: short version : I want to know if there are ways to edit lesson content pages other than the standard interface. If I edit page content by directly updating the database , will that break anything? ----- Hi! I'm a novice moodler. Right now I'm trying to use it to put together an online emotion skills course that we're using in some research, and another version of the course that's being used in my institution's wellness program. In our current system, the most current version of the course content is stored in a shared text document that my collaborators and I are editing. When I want to update the moodle course, I have to go page-by-page through each lesson in the two courses, inserting changes from the text document. Then, if everything works on the development server , I have to do the whole thing twice more on the production server.* It's a painful process -- even with a fast connection, the hundreds of page loads really add up. I'd like to know if there's any way to edit lesson content pages other than loading each page in moodle and editing them one-by-one. What I'd really like to do is to keep the HTML for the entire course in a single master document, and use a script to update the moodle database to be consistent with that. So, I have two questions: 1) Is there anything that does that, or anything like it? 2) It looks like all page content is stored in one database field, mdl_lesson_pages.contents. If I have a master document that contains each page's ID and the latest version of its content (in HTML), can I just write a script that generates MySQL queries and update the lesson content that way? Or are there other things in the database that I might have to change as well? (again, assuming that I only edit pages that already exist, and that I don't make changes to answer options or anything else). Thanks much, - Michael * I know I could export the courses from one server to the other, but doing that seems to mess up the accounts of users who exist on both servers (not a very helpful description of the problem, but I haven't explored it in detail yet).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: One section no longer editable?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: One section no longer editable?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, Thank you for sharing your work around. Another great bit of creative thinking. Just an point I discovered as a non-techie. Those id's are probably assigned when the course was created and the numbering system is related to the entire site. If you had moved section 5 to section 2, the id would remain the same, but it might have taken you a bit longer to find the correct id. Discovered that when I was playing around with internal links within a course on a lesson page in the content area. ChrisLogic believes you are right, there has to be a size limit but that is for a skilled developer to answer in a different forum. Best Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: hyperlink to a user report
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a lesson and am giving a user the option to click and find out his total score right from within the lesson text. How can I create a hyperlink so that the current users report is displayed. I don't know how to pass the id parameter. Hope someone can help. cheers Namita

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: hyperlink to a user report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Namita, The link to a user report will look like this http://bluejay.cty.jhu.edu/grade/report/user/index.php?id=58 The id= at the end refers to the classroom's id number. So. Use the Switch Role to . . . drop down box at the top right of your classroom's front page . Switch to Student. Move your mouse over the link to "Grades" and copy the link location. That's the hyperlink you need. However , you can show the ongoing score within the lesson by going to Update this Lesson> Grade Options > Display ongoing score > Yes

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: hyperlink to a user report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ben and Namita, Nice. I added it to the MoodleDoc page on HTML linking as an idea. This trick can also be used in other activities , because a link is a link. I believe modules push their grades to Gradebook. Which I believe means that the student will have to complete the lesson (or activity) to see the grade. As Ben pointed out, there is the ongoing score setting. Happy New Year! Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: how to create the lesson to my student

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to create the lesson to my student
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I think you first need a Moodle site that can be reached by your students. Do you have that site? Remember Moodle is a program that works with a web server . The web server might be one hosted on the Internet, or one hosted on an intranet (school or classroom network), or one that is on a single computer (stand alone computer in your classroom or perhaps on a laptop) without any network connection. Adding/editing a lesson has help about creating a lesson. Finding and Selecting A Web Host as some information about web hosts. Hope this helps, - Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Lesson repeat
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello there! I created a course containing lessons. For various reasons I set the lesson repeat option to "no", so that participants can work through a particular lesson only once. When I demonstrate the features of this lesson in live-seminars I would like to show it as students would see it. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson repeat
ResponsesInList.Text: Not case by case, no, that would be a nice feature. You could though backup the coruse with the lesson in it, and restore it into a new course (or just import the lesson into a new course), in the new course, set repeat to yes for your demo.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson repeat
ResponsesInList.Text: Not case by case, no, that would be a nice feature. You could though backup the coruse with the lesson in it, and restore it into a new course (or just import the lesson into a new course), in the new course, set repeat to yes for your demo.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson repeat
ResponsesInList.Text: Creating a new user prior to the seminar, and then deleting that user afterward would seem to be the least technical way of accomplishing what you are looking for.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson repeat
ResponsesInList.Text: Adam's suggestion is the way I do it because we like to demo a sample quiz. I have a standard student. Before we demonstrate how the course is being run, I enroll the student. After the demo I un-enroll the student. If I enroll the student again, (for a second demo to the same class) Moodle thinks they are taking the quiz for the first time. In something like demo.moodle , the restore a course method is used. Forums and some other activities can be tricky when a student is un-enrolled after making entries.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reporting on Lesson Completion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ellen, Humm, you left out a criterion.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reporting on Lesson Completion
ResponsesInList.Text: As Chris mentioned, the easiest way to do this is to have "something" in the lesson autograde so that upon completion the "score" for that lesson for that student went from 0/X to 0+something/x. An example of the approach we us (that may help I hope). On the LAST page of a lesson, place a question (we use short answer) and have the "correct" graded response as *.  That is, anything input by the student will be scored as a correct grade.  Assign it X points. Now, as soon as the lesson is complete, the student will have X/total instead of 0/total. Hope that helps. Ken

ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, Chris and Ken, I figured I would probably need to use a workaround like what you both suggested by having something or another be graded. I enabled custom scoring and by default all questions were set to 0. I added one question at the end, an Acknowledge of Receipt that is graded. This is fine and works as far as getting a report export that I need. However, the users don't want that grade to be displayed since everyone will simply get 100% for answering the last question. I'll look into modifying the lesson code to remove the printing of grades. Many thanks again! Ellen

ResponsesInList.Title: Modify lesson mod for flowchart
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd like to add a 'troubleshooting' to a course but wanted to make it interactive. The lesson mod seemed like the logical choice because, after all, the branches are dependant upon the selection of the user. Either 'yes/no' or 'multiple choice' could be used for navigation. My idea works in the lesson mod but I'd like to skip the "that's correct" and "continue" page and simply jump to the pre-defined page I've selected from the dropdown box. Here's an example: What are the symptoms? a) No power b) No sound c) LED doesn't turn on If person selects "a" then they would be taken directly to "no power" page without seeing "That's correct!" and "CONTINUE". How can this be done? Do I need to modify the source code? Maybe there's a better way.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify lesson mod for flowchart
ResponsesInList.Text: See lesson as a decision tree with loop-back options (= a "matrix") Draw your tree on paper and create it into lesson, no changes needed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify lesson mod for flowchart
ResponsesInList.Text: This is what I did but I didn't like the idea that it gave me "That's correct" or "That's incorrect" messages as decisions were made. I was hoping to bypass these and hop directly from branch to branch.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify lesson mod for flowchart
ResponsesInList.Text: If you put custom feedback in you can replace "that's correct", for instance replacing both default feedback with "OK", or some other neutral response. That is if you don't want to modify the code as Mark suggested. Another way to handle it is to use branch tables rather than questions (which I think is what Ger was suggesting?), then there is no 'correct' or 'incorrect' answer, just a branch taken or not. Adding an set-up option to skip question feedback would be worthwhile in my opinion, could you add this to the bug tracker as a feature request?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify lesson mod for flowchart
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark, I thought I was going crazy, but I just realized that the "redirect" code added to continue.php, to get rid of the automatic question feedback, does not work in IE --it still shows the page, although it does then redirect.  Whereas in FF, the page isn't shown at all.  Can you offer a suggestion for this? If not, I'll just change the lang string for the response to something neutral. Thanks, P.S. Michael, although adding neutral custom feedback is an option (my questions are neither right nor wrong as the example above), using a branch table isn't because I want to give points for the answers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify lesson mod for flowchart
ResponsesInList.Text: You could try putting an exit(); after the redirect.  This will stop the php code execution.  If you want, you could put a print_footer function call before the exit(); statement. To have a button to the course in the footer use this call: print_footer($course); To not have any buttons in the footer use this call: print_footer('none'); Hope this all helps, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify lesson mod for flowchart
ResponsesInList.Text: You do need to modify the source code if you wish to use the lesson code.  Please refer to this forum post: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=23779&parent=125604 You will want to implement the same code changes as I suggested at the bottom of the forum post except for the if statement.  That if statement is there so only essay questions will not show feedback.  So, if you remove the if statement that is wrapping around the redirect , then no feedback will be shown for any question. Cheers, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Images will be removed in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: I am tring to add an image to a lesson. I can put in on the server with the image manager from the editor. I am also able to select the image with the tool on the image button. The image will also be put on the lesson page. But when i save the lesson page, the image will be removed. The resulting HTML code is just this tag: I tried a lot, but i could not find any solution to put a image there. I am using the current version of the 1.5 Branch. Does anybody know a solution for that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Images will be removed in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, You stumbled onto a bug that we just found the other day.  What happens is the lesson page gets ran through clean_param($var, PARAM_CLEAN).  This is done to increase security.  What I didn't know is that it strips all the values out of html tags.  I looked at the clean_param function and it looks like it shouldn't do this, but it does. A quick fix to your problem is to open up mod/lesson/locallib.php and go to about line 1152 (which is very near to the end of the file). Next find this line: if ($form = data_submitted()) { ABOVE  if ($form = data_submitted()) {  put this line: return data_submitted();

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Images will be removed in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: this is still happening in the cvs HEAD version. On top of that the the proposed fix does not appear to work. maybe clean_param is called once too often? I 'll see if I can disable clean_param by returning immediately. edit: i can't. The html is accepted, but somewhere some of the tags are stripped out. I guess I'll have to dig in lesson/view.php It appears to be cleaning the outgoing text even further. :wq

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Images will be removed in lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: ok found that one: in view.php line 538 and 540 the page content is vetted by format_text() I added FORMAT_HTML to the call, and <input> (the tag that was stripped) to weblib.php. Now I can get my experiments to move one step further... (trying to add hook to external scripts in the lesson module, please let me know if somebody else is already doing that) Maybe the sanitation of the user input being done at more points in the codeflow is too much?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: End of Lesson,  what does it do?
ResponsesInList.Text:
End of Lesson takes the student to the end of the lesson and then computes their score, stores it in the database and then reports the student's grade. When viewing the lesson as a student, if I click that choice, it flashes a score on the screen
momentarily and then exits out to the main menu of the course. This might be happening because the "Show Grades" is turned off for the course.  If so, turn it on and you will get a different behavior. ResponsesInList.Title: Lesson question not following logic specified
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm trying to develop lessons (using Moodle version 1.9).  I want the students to do the questions at staged points through a lecture, so my first question is a "numerical" question with a four digit number that I will give when  I want the students to attempt the first question. Here are my settings: Page Contents: "Enter the code given in class to see question 1" Answer 1: 4949 Response 1: Correct.  Proceed to question 1. Jump to: Next Page  Score 1: 0 Answer 2: blank Response 2: Blank Jump to: This page  Score 2: 0 All the rest are blank. It is my expectation that if I put in the correct pass number, the program should give my response 1 and go on to the next question. If any other answer is given, it should give a default response or no response, and repose the question 1. What in fact happens is this: If the correct answer is put in, the response is: Not quite. Would you like to try again? It provides two buttons: "Yes, I'd like to try again." and "No, I just want to continue to next question." If I click on the first, it reposes the question.  If I click on the second, it takes me to the 2nd question. If I put in a wrong number the response is exactly the same as above.  The only difference between the button responses is if you click the one that says I'd like to continue, it does not go on to the next question, but reposes the first question. Now it is doing what it should but the responses don't seem to correspond with how the program should work.  Any suggestions? Note: in the main lesson settings, I have the setting for "display default feedback" set to "no."  For what it's worth, I've had it set to yes and I get the same results.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson question not following logic specified
ResponsesInList.Text: Yea that happens. I have edited the language pack so that the two options are Yes I would like to try again and Practice Makes Perfect- you must try again but I also give feed back tickling the student to the needed response- for example you should re read page blah blah in your text book

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson question not following logic specified

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson activity

The prompt for bringing you back to the previous page uses the information stored in the database for pages that you performed an action (like answering a question or choosing a branch) on the current lesson attempt.  I believe that just dropping into a lesson by accessing the page via the URL doesn't actually leave any trail showing that you were in the lesson. In either case, could you please file a bug report in the tracker about this inconsistent behavior. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing/Exporting Lesson content
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing/Exporting Lesson content
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Keith, I'm trying to understand your problem, by re-phrasing all the various phases. 1. Inserting a link to an image into the text of a lesson " When I am creating a lesson, I use the link tab to link to a file on the local system. " I suppose you mean that, when creating the various lesson pages (questions, answers, etc.) you would like e.g. to insert a link to an image file and thus you click on the Insert Image button (I don't see a "link tab " there). If so, then the image you want to insert is either: already present in your My Files directory (or an Image sub-directory of My Files ) on your local Moodle Course; residing somewhere on your local computer, then you first have to upload it to a My Files directory before selecting its link. 2. Copying your lesson to the production server How do you do this? The only way I know to "copy" a lesson is to backup your course - including only the lessons - and restore it to your production server course. Then, the link to the images you inserted into your lesson text is automatically re-written to point to the proper My Files directory on your online course. Of course, correct linking assumes that the structure of My Files in both courses (online & local) is the same and... that the various images present on your local My Files/Images directory have also been uploaded some way onto your distant My Files/Images site directory! I hope that helps, Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing/Exporting Lesson content
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joseph: Thanks for the response.  Let me try to explain further.  What I am doing is inserting text, and then "inserting a web link" (the picture is of a link chain in the html editor).  When you choose your file from the browser, the link lists something like " http://172.27.200.252/moodle/file.php/2/Topic1.pdf " (assuming that the computer that you are writing the course on is identified by that ip address). Then, when you restore the course, let's say to the ip of 192.168.0.8,  (the link in this case would look like " http://192.168.0.8/moodle/file.php/2/Topic1.pdf ") but the lesson cannot find the file, because it is still looking for 172.27.200.252. ( http://172.27.200.252/moodle/file.php/2/Topic1.pdf , which doesn't exist on this server). I've temporarily solved the problem by assigning a domain name to the ip, and then, when I work at home, temporarily assign that domain to the computer that I'm working on (assuming that I'm not online). I believe that moodle works this way because it sits "on top" of apache, and needs either the ip or domain to identify the server that it is getting the content from -- (localhost would work, UNTIL you tried to access the site from a remote computer, in which case it will look to itself [the local computer] to find the content -- I know, I've already tried . . .) Any thoughts would be appreciated.  Thanks, K.

ResponsesInList.Title: Grades for all Lessons in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I have about 8 Lessons in my course, I want access and calculate all the lesson grades in a course so the student overall result includes the sum of all the lesson questions that he has answered so far. Is this possible directly through moodle or by using any of its API's? My moodle version is 1.8

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grades for all Lessons in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Maram, You should be able to click on "Grades", in the "Administration Section" of your course, then up the top you will see two tabs, "View Grades", and "Set Preferences". Click on "Set Preferences;" then click on "Use Advanced Features." Once you do this you will see more tabs. " Set Categories ," "Set Weights ," " Set Grade Letters ," and " Grade Exceptions." You will need to click on "Set Categories." Then create a category named "Lessons." After that you will be able to set all of your lessons to that category. When you "View Grades" again you will see the lessons with their score next to the total available for lessons, A further refinement you might make is to weight your lessons, and/ or set other categories such as Quizzes, or Tests etc. I hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Linking to .lnk file on network drive
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a link to a shortcut on my local server that allows a video playing program to load and load a video file. This is intended to give students the easiest possible way to access a video file using Moodle. I'm using a <a> tag with the following as href; file://fs01/avdata/Geography/Jimmy's%20Global%20Harvest%20(part%202).lnk However the file won't open when left-clicking on it. Only right-clicking, saving it locally and then opening it does the video open. To clarify, I don't want the video to be accessible outside of the college network. I just want students to be able to left-click on the link and have the shortcut load up the program and then the video to make it as easy as possible for them.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking to .lnk file on network drive
ResponsesInList.Text: That doesn't link to a file on your server it links to a file on THE USER's machine. And, of course, it won't be there. You need to put your video file somewhere accessible over the web (i.e. the url starts http://...). In addition - what is an '.lnk' file anyway? That's not a video file so it probably won't work anyway.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking to .lnk file on network drive
ResponsesInList.Text: To clarify, the video file is on a shared network drive. Myself and another user have tested it and we can both access it as can others. Again, I'll reiterate that I do not want the video accessible online outside of our internal network. A .lnk is a shortcut file in windows.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking to .lnk file on network drive
ResponsesInList.Text: Oh ok. So what *does* happen when they left click on the link? (Sorry... I'm very unfamiliar with Windows) Is there a particular reason that you are pointing them to a link file? Why don't you point them at the *actual* file? I can imagine a possible issue where something along the line doesn't know what to do with a .lnk file either.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking to .lnk file on network drive
ResponsesInList.Text: Literally nothing. You left click and there's no response; no pop up saying it's blocked, no error message, nothing. This is in both IE and Firefox. Pointing to the actual file doesn't work, it causes IE to crash.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking to .lnk file on network drive
ResponsesInList.Text: I believe that Firefox actively blocks such file links - see http://kb.mozillazine.org/Links_to_local_pages_don%27t_work (it's effectively a local file in this case). I try to avoid IE but it does seem to be even more unhelpful about such thinks. This brings me back to where I started. I wouldn't dream of doing what you did because I just know it would be trouble. You are relying on the behaviour of particular browsers doing something that they were never really intended to do. I would mount the remote share to my server (sorry, don't know the Windows terminology but hopefully you know where I'm going) and then make the file area available using your web server. Therefore the file will be http://....something... - make the real file available not the .lnk. Using .lnk relies on what the browser thinks of an .lnk file which is anybody's guess. I'm not saying what you are doing is impossible - it's just that you are making your lives really difficult for no obvious advantage.

ResponsesInList.Title: skip questions already answered correctly

When a student gets the compreshension question wrong it returns them to the page where the information can be found. That works like I want it to. My problem is when a student has already answered a question correctly, I don't want the to have to answer it again (which it currently is doing...they have the answer all the questions they've already answered). Any way to get this behavior? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: skip questions already answered correctly
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andy, I am not sure exactly what you mean. B1, B2, B3, Q1, B4, B5, Q2, B6, B7, Q3 is Alternative 1 B1, B2, B3, Q1, Q2, B4, B5, Q3, Q4, B6, B7, Q5 etc. is Alternative 2 I see two problems. However, one solution might be to change lesson settings so that they only can answer a question once (Flow Control, max number of attempts set to 1). That may not be acceptable to you but it is a solution for both alternatives. The other potential problem you did not mention is that after being sent back then the students have to review all the pages. For example: If a students misses Q2 and is sent back to B3. The navigation order for B3 will still be in place. If you change the lesson setting to 1 attempt, then they will jump to B4, then go to B5 etc. In Alternative 1 this could be a lot of material. This falls under lesson planning. In Alternative 1, if an answer in Q3 indicates they missed the content of B2, then you might send them to another page which explains the concept differently. Then send them back to Q3 (which of course they answered) so they will automatically go to the next page (generally speaking). This can start to create lots of loops for a teacher to remember. Hope this assists you. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tooltip and popup
ResponsesInList.Text: The idea is that header.html is loaded at all pages before content and footer after content. Some parts of javascripts must be included inside head tags, some parts may be just after body tag and sometimes script tags must be at the end of document and then you must paste them to footer.html Where do you have script tags in that web page (inside head or body tags)? Lesson like all other modules and blocks are part of content between header and footer so you may use that link anywhere. You just need to open editor, press <> ,paste links using script and save. Using iframe tags is sometimes easier (javascript is loaded from other webpage or script to iframe)

ResponsesInList.Title: Delay if wrong answer is selected
ResponsesInList.Text: My Moodle 1.6.5 is working fine. My problem is with my students. Some want to learn and some don't. My system must be configured so the students can guess and eventually proceed through the course. I had one student view 250 pages in 90 minutes. I don't think he was even reading the questions. I am sure he was not reading any of the material. My wife is a Behaviorists. She asked if the program was capable of creating a 5 minute delay should the student select the incorrect answer at the end of a lesson. Could you imagine the positive impact if a student found that by answering correctly they could finish sooner. Are there any time constraints associated with the lesson module? Is there any work being done to added time constraints? Who or where would I put this suggestion to have it considered? Thanks ... Michael

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Delay if wrong answer is selected
ResponsesInList.Text: I call these user the speed clickers. I agree with your wife, make them pay in what they value - "time". I am not aware of any lesson delay for speed clicker. I have two basic suggestions. 1. We send them back in the logical order when they miss a question. "They need review if they missed that one" is the official policy. As the Behaviorist implies, the speed clickers want to zip through our branch and question pages. It doesn't take our adult trainees long to realize it takes less time to read the questions we scatter about than randomly guess the answers. You might need to be clever about this. Don't do every question the same way for wrong answers. When they miss "the answer", send them back to the "this page" some times, send them forward as if they got it correct, send them back 10 pages at other times. Insert a page in the logical order that is intentionally skipped but guesses will hit it. Speed clickers will figure out the back browser button to skip the review and answer the question correctly, so random really makes them pay attention because of the cost of being lazy or non-motivated. I have varied my standards from lesson to lesson (hey I am lazy too) just to keep them guessing about the pattern. Also remember, some of these students will not realize they just answered 500 questions and only needed to answer 50 questions. Just like they might not realize you sent them to a time out area for 5 minutes (boring is boring). So you may have to tell them what you are doing a couple of times early on in the lesson. Not only in the intro, but as feed back "Sorry you missed this question, please review this material". Can you find a reward that a student has to find? Puzzle pieces, build a magic phrase that allows them to draw a prize (a credit for a book report? an apple for the teacher?) . 2. Install Activity Locking in 1.6.5 or upgrade to 1.8 and use the built in Lesson dependency settings. One of the contingencies in either of these is time spent in another activity/lesson. Note: there maybe a problem with time because in the past it was not cumulative for all attempts of the lesson, just the current attempt or most recent attempt.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Delay if wrong answer is selected
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris I am using AL 2.4 on Moodle 1.6.5. I selected this version and 1.6.5 because the comments indicated that they were the most stable. I do not see any time contingencies. Thanks for the help ... Michael

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Displaying only next uncomplete lesson
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mike, Yes but not with a standard Moodle module. We use a flavor of Activity Locking which is a third party module and keep it simple. One of the features is to hide uncompleted activities , another is to mark completed activities. I don't think it hides completed activities. It is otherwise similar in concept to Dependency in Lesson. The rumor is that this kind of conditional activity will be part of Moodle 2.0 . I could go on but the CA forum and AL MoodleDoc page will get you going. Best - Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: to subscribe a category
ResponsesInList.Text: I want to this: I student sign in the site. whrn click the category ask to subscribe. not subcribe the lessons. example: category is word's lessons. sub category is lesson 1. and lesson is Use words. normally, when students click use words, moodle ask do you want to subcribe this lesson. I don't want it. I want to that: whrn students click category (word's lessons), moodle ask do you want to subcribe this? when student subcribe the category, they see all lessons. can we do this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: to subscribe a category
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, In MoodleSpeak, I think you mean "courses" not "lessons". I made the same mistake when I first studied Moodle. I may move your question out of this forum but let me try to answer your question first. In Moodle language, a Moodle site has courses. One course can be placed in a group of courses which is called a category. Students can enroll in (subscribe to) a course. Here is some more information about site course categories . Inside each course are activities modules, resources and blocks. Activities and resources are placed in sections (groups). These sections can be called "topics" or "weeks". A Lesson Module is an Activity module. Each Lesson can have a password. It is possible to make a student take the first lesson before taking the second lesson. You are not talking about this kind of lesson. I think in Moodle language you are asking, "Can a student enroll in a category of courses? I do not want them to have to enroll in each course in a category, just enroll 1 time." I think the answer is "yes", when you set up some " Metacourse" (please follow the link to Moodle documentation for more words). People say it can be tricky to set up a Metacourse the first time for a new Moodle users. In theory here is how a Metacourse works. A Meta course allows a student to enroll in one course and then automatically enrolled in other courses. This is what you want.

ResponsesInList.Title: Need more answer options for Multiple Choice question

In Lessons, The Multiple Choice question type only allows five answers. How can we have more possible answers? We are using Moodle 3.0. Any pointers would be greatly appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need more answer options for Multiple Choice question
ResponsesInList.Text: You can read about the setting here: https://docs.moodle.org/31/en/Lesson_settings#Maximum_Number_of_Answers When setting up a Lesson, expand the Appearance setting by clicking on Show more. Maximum number of answers, is what your're looking for. It can be changed any time, even after making some questions.  If you drop to a lower number, it will not affect questions you've already created.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need more answer options for Multiple Choice question
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you AL -- for the prompt answer, and for the documentation pointer! Best regards.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need more answer options for Multiple Choice question
ResponsesInList.Text: You're welcome. Right about the time I saved my post, I realized you were using Moodle 3.0. My wife was asking me to do something, so I didn't get a chance to edit and fix the link, so just let me point out that anytime you have a documentation page like that, you can change the numbers to go to the correct page for your version of Moodle. In this case, if you replace the 31 with 30, you will get the correct page for your Moodle. Many times it won't matter, like in this case, but sometimes there are drastic changes from one version of Moodle to another, and looking at the correct page for your Moodle can be important.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scenarios
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frank: Frequency and severity are exactly the kinds of distinctions that the lesson module is good at forcing students to make. It's what we've used the lesson module for. Example: You are a firefighter and you get a call that a warehouse is on fire. What should you take to fight the fire? (a) Fire extinguisher, (b) Water buffalo, (c) Fire truck. Okay, so you pick fire truck. Looks like the fire is coming from an oil tank. What should you use? (a) Water, (b) CO2, (c) Foam. You chose water. Okay, here's what happens: fire out of control! Better choose something else. Etc. You can take the learner down each path as far as you want. Hypercard did something similar, and you could link web pages or Powerpoint slides to one another. But I love the lesson module b/c it's so easy to set up and use, and it allows an instructor to track student progress (by way of scores). Hope this helps. - Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scenarios
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frank and Peter (and other moodlers using the Lesson module for scenarios). For anyone reading French, you may be interested in the article I wrote about my use of the Lesson module for a typical "maze" scenario activity. « Un cas particulier du scénario dans l'apprentissage des langues : le labyrinthe (action maze) », Alsic , Vol. 11, n° 2 | 2008 . Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scenarios
ResponsesInList.Text: Merci, Joseph, for sharing the article. I don't read French very well, but I could still understand the basic drift, and I enjoyed seeing the snippets of your scenario. I've not experimented much with Cloze, short-answer, and other types of questions in the lesson module. What I find most challenging about creating a credible scenario is supplying answers without leading the student. In other words, once I mention a choice, the student knows the issue is possibly important, just by my calling attention to it. The real trick is to lay out all of the cues in a situation without calling attention to any one of them. That's how most authentic performance situations work, in my experience. - Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scenarios
ResponsesInList.Text: And, not to throw in unintentional distractors by emphasizing something accidentally.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scenarios
ResponsesInList.Text: Peter: ***What I find most challenging about creating a credible scenario is supplying answers without leading the student. I quite agree that this point is really challenging. It is not particularly linked to the Lesson/scenario situation but to the teaching situation in general. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Using Clusters and Correct/Incorrect Responses

How do I get any wrong response to move to the next question or end of the cluster. I have bothe numerical questions and short answer, in all cases there is only one correct response. So how do I get it to do something when an incorrect response (anything else) is submitted?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Clusters and Correct/Incorrect Responses
ResponsesInList.Text: Crystal, If I am not mistaken, that behaviour is controlled by what you put in the Maximum number of attempts setting when you created the Lesson. Set to 1, students only get one shot at the answer, then the lesson moves on to another page. If you were to have 2 in that setting, they get two tries at getting the correct answer. And so on... Hope this helps, AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Lesson Completion Settings and Reports Vary
ResponsesInList.Text: We are using 3.2 and adaptable theme. We have a series of lessons in a course that have two completion criteria set: student must reach end of lesson and student must be engaged with lesson a certain length of time. We also have one quiz question that becomes unlocked at the end of the course when students register completion with each lesson within the course. I have noticed a few students are able to reach the end quiz question with their profile outline completion report showing that a few lessons have been started but not yet complete. The Activity Completion report within the course shows that the student did complete the activity with a check mark in the table with the listings of other students. The majority of students it appears to work and report as intended that completion is registered in both locations - the course's activity completion report and the student's profile outline report. I assumed that the student would need to both be engaged in the lesson for x amount of time and reach the end of the lesson. Can you only have one completion criteria set for a lesson? I do not have student must view the activity to complete as that is already covered if you have it open a certain length of time. Our lesson consists of a content page, followed by a page with a video, then the end of lesson. I did not want students to be on the content page for the entire time allotted for the lesson and not reach the video, thus I added they must also reach the end of lesson. Might there be a better way to achieve this? SCORM activities are not an option for us. thank you Sandy

ResponsesInList.Title: Lesson Short Answer Scoring Failure!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All: One of my teachers reported a strange bug today, and I can not get to the bottom of it! When a student gets a short answer correct in a lesson, the correct feedback is displayed, and the designated jump is executed as expected. However, no points are added to the total score. In addition, the lesson score is recorded as 100% upon quitting the lesson after correctly answering only the first question (as long as it is not a short answer question) even if the minimum number of questions is set to 18 for a lesson that contains 18 questions. This bug has just appeared in the last day or two, and no changes have been made to the installation in that time. I have tried upgrading the entire installation to this week's latest version, and I've repaired and optimized all database tables without solution. The problem occurs even in a new lesson that freshly created. This is obviously a serious issue for us! Does anyone have any insight into this problem?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson Short Answer Scoring Failure!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Carl, We have seen the same problem since the update to 1.9.4 ( MDL 18347 ). However, while we wait for the issue to be addressed, we are mitigating the problem by changing the settings of affected lessons. We found that the problem only occurs in lesson that do not have custom grading turned on (i.e. lessons that work only via "Jump to next page" as a way of grading). If you turn on custom grading in the lesson settings and you give e.g. a 1 point score for the correct alternatives in the short answer questions (and in the correct answers to other questions!), the lesson grading will work. It is probably possible to do this for all lessons via an SQL query in the database, but I have not yet determined the exact syntax of such a query and, then again, you may not want to turn all lessons to custom grading. I think there would have to be two SQL queries: One to turn custom grading on in all lessons One to turn the score to 1 for all lesson answers in which jumpto is -1 and score is 0. Someone with better knowledge of MySQL could probably churn out the correct queries. Rgrds, Paul.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson Short Answer Scoring Failure!
ResponsesInList.Text: You said that you have only found this problem for courses where custom scoring is not on. I have custom scoring set to yes for my lesson. Some students are awarded points for the correct answers to short answer questions while others are not.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson Short Answer Scoring Failure!
ResponsesInList.Text: Lisa > Some students are awarded points for the correct answers to short answer questions while others are not. This sounds quite impossible. There is no reason that the Lesson module should behave differently for different students if they answer the Lesson questions exactly in the same way. Since this cannot be reproduced on other moodlers' installations, it cannot be tested or fixed. You should go to the Lesson report (and the course activity report) and retrieve as much information as possible on what exactly those students did, i.e. exactly how they answered those short answer questions, in order to find out what happened. You should also let us know what your SA questions look like, etc. All the best, Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create Content Page link missing from lesson edit 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: @Karen, sorry to contradict, but you've got it partially wrong. As I said in my previous post (probably a bit tersely), in Moodle 1.9 we had pages called "Branch Tables", which have been re-named to "Content Pages" in Moodle 2. See this discussion . So, in Moodle 1.9, if you want to create a page which is not a question but contains information content, you must create a Branch Table page . In Moodle 2, you'll create a Content Page . In Moodle 1.9 it was indeed possible to create a Question page (of the Multiple Choice type) without any answer . That page would sort of behave like a "Branch Table", i.e. it would provide a "Continue" button which, upon being clicked, would jump to the next page in the lesson. It was in fact quite illogical to have a "Question without answers", and using this feature instead of using the "Branch Table" feature led to the problem described by Karen when upgrading to Moodle 2. So my advice to the original poster (and anyone still using moodle 1.9) is to use Branch Table pages, not a MCQ question page with no answers, in order to avoid problems when upgrading to Moodle 2. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Error opening and closing dates in Calendar
ResponsesInList.Text: The lesson module in our Moodle 1.5.2 does not display separate opening and closing dates in the calendar, but a double listing (two messages saying: lesson opens, lesson closes) at the closing date. Does anyone else have this problem and is there a fix for it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error opening and closing dates in Calendar
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, What appears as a bug here is due to the way the Moodle calendar interprets the period of time during which a "lesson" is open as compared to current date. Example: Today is Nov. 6th Case 1 (normal behavior) in lesson settings, a lesson is set to be available from Nov. 7th until Nov. 10th In the calendar the only highlighted date is Nov. 7th, and dates 8th through 10th are "boxed" (i.e. they display a top and bottom border). In the calendar, if you click on Nov. 7th, it takes you to the calendar day view, where you can see the details of lesson opening and closing. Case 2 (the buggy situation) in lesson settings, a lesson is set to be available from Nov. 1st until Nov. 10th In the calendar the only highlighted date is Nov. 10th, in which we can see the double message you mention: Lesson opens; lesson closes... twice Obviously, Case2 should be considered as a bug since when a lesson's opening date is overdue we shoud not get the doubly double message in the due date box. What we should really see is a single message saying "lesson closes" that's all. I have posted bug report #4279 Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedding PPT (again) using PPT for mac
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, I have an identical set up to you - I work in a Mac, use Office for Mac 2011 and our main moodle sites are 1.9.+. I have never been able to get import PPTs to work. I'm sorry I have no solution for you, but really wanted to share to stop you spending time looking for a solution - I've spent days on this myself and some while ago I gave up trying. You say you are trying to embed them - the import PPTs to lessons is not embedding: it's converting the PPTs to lesson pages.   Embedding you can do - but this means saving as a movie and showing it in an AV filter. Is there another way you will be satisfied with showing the content or does it have to be lesson format? Unless you want to include in-page questions, why not consider this? It would save you duplicating your work into a lesson. If you only want lesson pages I really think it's not good news - it means recreating the slides again within the lesson. Perhaps someone else has recently found an alternative, but I don't expect so as those people that are clever enough to develop are moving on to concentrate on 2.0. Sorry.

ResponsesInList.Text: Amen!  Excellent point Scarlet.  Importing is not embedding. You can embed a flash file into a page,  that is basically your PPT.  Or you can embed individual screenshots of your PPT into individual lesson pages (I have a hacked localhost which automates thisprocess in 1.9 for 200 images). But alas, converting a PPT into lesson pages can be very frustrating.  I just wish we would drop the Import PPT idea and move to importing a series of text pages (similar to GIFT files) and importing a series of image files at any point in the lesson. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Is a student response to an essay question a "post"
ResponsesInList.Text: What is a dadgum post in the reports - Statistics? A teacher responding to a forum, or a students post in a forum should both be counted as a "post". In a lesson module, a student answers an essay question and that should be counted as a "post". A teacher responds to a student essay and that should be counted as a "post". In the Assignment activity, A student responds to an online text assignment and that answer to the question posited in the activity should be counted as a post. If a teacher responds back to the students answer, with a comment, that should be counted as a post. The point is, if we are to measure activity in the course by views and posts, everything that is considered a "post" to the course, ought to be counted. Otherwise, it is very difficult to "administer" the course and understand either student or teacher activity. This is yet another piece of the puzzle that both Instructure and Brain Honey have solved, that inspire confidence in people who are making decisions about which LMS to use. I am getting to the point, where it seems like Moodle Statistics must be considered as unimportant. What is it replaced with?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson Module Question Page jumps to blank page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Crystal, Before we can answer your question we need more information. Which version of Moodle are you currently using (e.g. 1.9.11 or 2.0 or 2.1 or...)? ResponsesInList.Title: Raw Score on Multiple Attempts
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently I have a lesson set so that students can retake a lesson, and the number of attempts per question is set to 6. For the lesson itself, I have it set to take the highest score. My question is: Is there a way so that the raw score of the student for the lesson attempt does not go higher with each new attempt at a question after getting it wrong? For example: 1st Time in the Lesson (Only one question in the lesson) Question 1: Student gets the wrong answer. They are then allowed to try again: Question 1 (second time): Student gets the correct answer. Raw Score: 1/2 (Even though there is only one question.) Can I change a setting somewhere so that the lesson only takes the highest score from multiple attempts at the same question, and then not have it increase the raw score by 1 for each wrong answer?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Raw Score on Multiple Attempts
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Drew, For the sake of discussion, my understanding is that Lesson resets itself with each lesson attempt by a student. Lesson setting has a setting for how the lesson's grade will be calculated in gradebook for a retake. The Lesson activity is not a Quiz activity. Quiz has a penalty feature with each question and some other features that might meet some of your needs. Quiz does not have a jump feature. I suppose you could use the jump feature to achieve the result you want. However, you have to realize that what you the teacher knows and sees is different that what the student sees (and is clueless about). And it requires the teacher understand all the potential paths the student can take. There is not a global lesson setting to do what you want (unless you tweak the code, of course). Thus if it is important to you, you will have to plan and devote some time to it. Here is how I would do it in a Lesson. For example, imagine you had 2 pairs of identical questions in your lesson. Q1a, Q1b, Q2a, Q2b. The student who answers Q1a correctly, goes to Q2a. The student who misses Q1a, goes to Q1b via the wrong answer jumps. Any answer in Q1b will go to Q2a. We could keep repeating this with Q2, Q3 etc. The next thing is to consider your custom scores for each answer in the identical pair of questions. Say you gave a 2 for the right answer in Q1a and a zero for wrong answers. In Q1b you could give 1 point for the correct answer and zero for the wrong answers. This reaches the goal you described. Since the student is only taking the lesson once, in lesson settings I would set the max attempts at 1. Now the question becomes if you want them to take this lesson again and what have you set for the retake setting. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 2: Getting a Grip on the Lesson Activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Just thought I would let you know I have written a short book on the Lesson Activity: Moodle 2: Getting a grip on the Lesson Activity Covers the basics of using it and some ideas too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Partially correct answer in multiple-choice, multianswers question
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I'm trying to obtain the following result in a multiple-choice, multi-answers question embedded into a lesson: X Correct answer X Another correct answer Wrong answer Another wrong answer = Score 2 on 2 points X Correct answer Another correct answer X  Wrong answer Another wrong answer = Score 1 on 2 points However, Moodle seems to work in an "all or nothing" world... (the second option is graded 0 on 2 points). Would it be possible to change this behaviour? I tried both selecting and de-selecting Custom scoring in the lesson's editing page (I always ticked the multi-answers option in the question's editing page). Thank you very much for your help! Daniele

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Partially correct answer in multiple-choice, multianswers question
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for posting this Daniele and for explaining it so clearly.  I am having the exact same problem and it has been frustrating.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Partially correct answer in multiple-choice, multianswers question
ResponsesInList.Text: Ciao Daniele, I'm sorry I had misunderstood your question in my first reply here. I have now deleted my post because it did not address your problem. I was misled by your use of " embedded into a lesson". I thought you were using the Embed questions filter plugin... You are actually referring to the standard Multichoice question page in a Lesson activity. And you are right, a multiple-choice, multi-answers question works as an "all or nothing" question. This cannot be changed. You must realize that the Moodle Lesson activity is not really suited for assessment. The number of question types it recognizes is very limited and the options within each type are very limited as well. If you want a better assessment tool, then the Quiz activity offers plenty of question types and plenty of settings. In my experience the Lesson activity is a great tool for branching scenarios and as a learning tool, not so much as a testing tool.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remain on same page until correct answer given, even for no credit
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, Here is how I have handled this in the past. Make two copies of the each question page. Make the first copy one a student sees so that it gives a score for the correct answer then that answer only goes on to the NEXT question. All wrong answers go to the second copy of the first question which has all the scoring set to zero but the correct answer will go to the NEXT question. Takes a little extra work but gives the desired results of no score after the first attempt at an answer. HTH and is understandable. AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remain on same page until correct answer given, even for no credit
ResponsesInList.Text: Michael, Now I quite understand what you want to achieve but, unfortunately it is not possible with the Lesson settings. Here are the settings which should work: Provide option to try a question again: yes. Maximum number of attempts: 1 When student gives a correct answer: display feedback for correct answer When student gives incorrect answer: display feedback for incorrect answer and message " Unfortunately you cannot earn this one point, because your response was not correct. Would you like to keep guessing, just for the sheer joy of learning (but for no point credit)? " with relevant 2 buttons (go back / go forward). Settings 1 and 2 work with #3 (correct answer + feedback) but not with #4 (incorrect feedback is not displayed). I have reported this as MDL-34102 for which you can vote. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson grade = 0% for all students
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Davina, Tell us, what version you are using? I don't have a solution so an expert needs to step in and this information is important. This may also be something for a different forum, such as Gradebook here. Here is what I did. I played in demo.moodle.org ( currently 1.9 Beta 4 ). I added a Lesson in section 8 as teacher with 1 question. Student took it and indeed I did not see it. When the teacher clicked on Lessons it was there but not in grades. This seemed to duplicate your problem. ( FYI : Somebody had changed the theme to blue and added another course that the student could not see.) I went in as admin and looked at Grades setting in the course admin block, even assigned the teacher as the teacher to the new lesson. No help, so I went off to MoodleDocs . When I returned to demo.moodle a new hour had started. In my second attempt, the theme was a standard white. I added a Lesson above the first section with a question. The student took the lesson and missed the question. The student saw the grade (0%) on the last row, much to my surprise! They took the lesson again and answered the question correctly and got a 50% (the mean, as I had set it up). The teacher saw the grade in the last column on the right. I added a second 1 question lesson. The student got this one correct. This lesson appeared at the bottom of the grades icon list. So at least in demo.moodle I conclude that student's that get a zero on a lesson will see 0%, which is their score. Students who do not attempt a lesson will see a - , as in the lesson which was in section 8 which they did not attempt. I wonder if I set the max score under lesson settings for the demo lesson in section 8 to say 10 (instead of zero), what would happen in the grade book.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lesson grade = 0% for all students
ResponsesInList.Text: Most probably, here is the situation you had: You didn't specify a value greater than '0' of 'Maximum in the lesson's settings. I leave it zero, the lesson's grades will not be shown anywhere it should be shown, so YOU HAVE TO GET INTO lesson's settings and change it to larger number other than '0'.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Questions about short answer and regular expressions

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Questions about short answer and regular expressions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, In the Lesson module, if you use the Short answer question type with the Use Regular Expressions option checked, then the catch-all expression is " .* " (dot + asterisk), not just " * " (asterisk on its own) as in the Quiz module. Please read the online Help and look at the examples provided for that question type to understand how it works. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error: could not find records
ResponsesInList.Text: It appears that the error is caused by the timer feature in lesson/view.php (around line 420) ------------------------ // clock code // get time information for this user $timer = new stdClass; if(!has_capability('mod/lesson:manage', $context)) { if (!$timer = get_records_select('lesson_timer', "lessonid = $lesson->id AND userid = $USER->id", 'starttime')) { error('Error: could not find records'); } else { $timer = array_pop($timer); // this will get the latest start time record } } ------------------------ However all timers are disabled (0) for my lessons... I am not sure to understand the purpose of the routine... Any thoughts would be most appreciated. Seb

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error: could not find records
ResponsesInList.Text: I turns out that the script is systematically interacting with the table timer_lesson (empty) even though I have disabled the timing feature. Perhaps for statistical purposes then? Anyhow, is there any way to prevent all references to the timer_lesson table? Would disabling the following be enough? Where should I do that in the setup? --- if (!has_capability('mod/lesson:manage', $context)) --- Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error: could not find records
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! Did you ever solve this problem? If so, how, if you don't mind me asking? I am getting similar error messages. Sacha

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error: could not find records
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Sacha, I don’t mind at all. I had to disable (/* comment */) all sections that were trying to update the lesson_timer table. However, this will completely disable the timer feature and will impact all your ongoing lessons so make sure that you don’t use any timers. I guess that it would be better to embed the sections below in a conditional statement (e.g. if ($lesson->timed)) instead of commenting but I didn’t have the time to try it. This fix was tried on v1.8.2+. Make sure you use Moodle’s debug feature before implementing this in order to ensure that it is the lesson_timer feature that is causing your problem. Try this at your own risks as I am no php guru. ====> In mod/lesson/view.php Comment the following (around line 420) -------------------------------- // clock code // get time information for this user $timer = new stdClass; if(!has_capability('mod/lesson:manage', $context)) { if (!$timer = get_records_select('lesson_timer', "lessonid = $lesson->id AND userid = $USER->id", 'starttime')) { error('Error: could not find and/or insert records in lesson_timer'); } else { $timer = array_pop($timer); // this will get the latest start time record } } $startlastseen = optional_param('startlastseen', '', PARAM_ALPHA); if ($startlastseen == 'yes') { // continue a previous test, need to update the clock (think this option is disabled atm) $timer->starttime = time() - ($timer->lessontime - $timer->starttime); $timer->lessontime = time(); } else if ($startlastseen == 'no') { // starting over // starting over, so reset the clock $timer->starttime = time(); $timer->lessontime = time(); } -------------------------------- and about 20 lines below, below the “update the clock” title -------------------------------- if (!update_record('lesson_timer', $timer)) { error('Error: could not update lesson_timer table'); } -------------------------------- ====> in mod/lesson/action/continue.php comment the following block: $timer = new stdClass; if (!has_capability('mod/lesson:manage', $context)) { if (!$timer = get_records_select('lesson_timer', "lessonid = $lesson->id AND userid = $USER->id", 'starttime')) { error('Error: could not find records'); } else { $timer = array_pop($timer); // this will get the latest start time record } if ($lesson->timed) { if ((($timer->starttime + $lesson->maxtime * 60) - time()) starttime + $lesson->maxtime * 60) - time()) starttime + $lesson->maxtime * 60) starttime + $lesson->maxtime * 60) - time()) wwwroot /mod/lesson/view.php?id=$cm->id&pageid=".LESSON_EOL."&outoftime=normal", get_string("outoftime", "lesson")); } } $timer->lessontime = time(); if (!update_record("lesson_timer", $timer)) { error("Error: could not update lesson_timer table"); } } -------------------------------- Hope this helps! S ---- NOTE: This fix is only for those who upgraded Moodle with an empty lesson_timer table.

ResponsesInList.Title: The lesson dependency, time spent, is not being added
ResponsesInList.Text: The lesson dependency, time spent, is not being added up to determine if a student has spent the required time in the (previous or some other) dependent-lesson. The documentation says "A typical use of this feature is to "daisy chain" a series of Lessons to make sure the students take the lessons in order." This does not imply forcing them to accomplish each lesson in one sitting, and so the code should not have been written to require it. Surely the code requiring it was an error and should be fixed - as shown below. The only change needed to fix the error is to initialize $duration and to sum it (+=), not replace it. (=) change lines 100-102 in mod/lesson/view.php (in versions 1.9.9 through 2.0.2 at least; earlier versions are only off by a few lines) From: // go through all the times and test to see if any of them satisfy the condition foreach($attempttimes as $attempttime) { $duration = $attempttime->lessontime - $attempttime->starttime; To: $duration=0; // go through all the times to see if the total satisfies the condition foreach($attempttimes as $attempttime) { $duration += $attempttime->lessontime - $attempttime->starttime; (We made this correction perhaps 2 years ago, tested it, and it has fixed the problem for us ever since.) Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The lesson dependency, time spent, is not being added
ResponsesInList.Text: There are enough examples of agencies and governments requiring "time spent" minimums on courses which are commonly and easily handled with the moodle lesson "time spent" dependency feature. The feature provides a simple solution to the common requirement. The bug is in the code that disallows any lesson work to be done "on the users own time" instead, of being unnecessarily forced to accomplish each lesson in one sitting "all-at-once". With the above code change, a student can progress through a lesson "on their own schedule"

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The lesson dependency, time spent, is not being added
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Greg, Moodle should do this feature (time spent dependency ) correctly or not at all. This works for my corporate environment. BTW this mod work fine in M2.2 too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Lessons In Sequence
ResponsesInList.Text: I have several courses broken up into 5-7 lessons. How can I ensure that the lessons are taken in sequence?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lessons In Sequence
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gerald, There are several ways. In 1.6 and onward, there is a way to make one lesson dependent upon another. This is set under lesson settings (updating lesson). There are 3 possible criterion time, completion and minimum score that can be used in combinations if desired. l See MoodleDocs access control There are some non standard modules for conditional activities : Activity locking or Score Lock. These are a little bit more complex, alter the Moodle database and allow most activities or sections to be dependent upon meeting certain conditions. Last I looked, these have not been updated for 1.7. Of course you can open and close lessons by dates to establish a sequence but that does not ensure a student has taken the lesson. Hope this helps

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lessons In Sequence
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much for your help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: reste lessons for (individual) students
ResponsesInList.Text: In lesson 1.5 when you go to edit a lesson's settings, near the bottom is the option labeled " Delete student attempts for this lesson (user id):" .  If you enter a student's user name in there it will delete everything that belongs to that student for that lesson.  Basically a reset. Please vote for bug report MDL-12194 if you want to support this request! Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: End of Lesson page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello - you can modify the lesson.php file - there are text strings, such as "congratulations - end of lesson reached" that you can edit to include your differing text. Please note though, that this will change the text for ALL end of lesson pages in your site. To do it individually for a course (or courses) you'd need to know a lot of php! Are you using version 1.9+ or 2? You can do this in both, but the menu names and manner in which you access these php strings has altered slightly. Basically in either, go to site administration and find the language editing - if you need specific information how to find these please say which version of Moodle you are using and I'll give you more advice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: End of Lesson page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey, thanks for replying! I am using moodle 2.2. I know php to get by.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: End of Lesson page
ResponsesInList.Text: You don't need to know any php for customizing your language strings. Just see the procedure in the Moodle Documentation (my message further down). Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: End of Lesson page
ResponsesInList.Text: H - no need for php in this instance then - you just type in and it replaces the text string for you. You must be an admin Go to site admin>language>language customisation choose the correct language from the drop down box click 'check out strings into the translator' (this may take a while) then continue In the selection box, scroll down until you find lesson.php and press 'show strings' Edit or add to the following text string : "Congratulations - end of lesson reached" (this is about 2/3rds down the page) click 'save and check in strings into files' this should do it - remember this changes EVERY end of lesson page!

ResponsesInList.Title: Feedback Help
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a nice little lesson working properly, with feedback for both correct and incorrect answers. My question is this: can I change the way feedback displays? I have run into some usability issues when doing some testing. Users complain that they have to see the entire question page again, and that they have to scroll down past it to see the feedback. I would like the feedback to show up at the top of the page. I am not very concerned that the lesson page show up as well on feedback, but if it is there, I would prefer it to show up BELOW the feedback. On a related note, it would be nice if a continue button were also at the top of the feedback page. Scrolling the page just to find a continue button when you have already read a page is really not good design. Any thoughts? Can I accomplish this with a small CSS hack? Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback Help
ResponsesInList.Text: Rob > I would like the feedback to show up at the top of the page. I am not very concerned that the lesson page show up as well on feedback, but if it is there, I would prefer it to show up BELOW the feedback. The problem is that the Lesson module is versatile and can be used for all kind of activities, unlike the Quiz module, which is clearly aimed at asking questions and - optionally - providing feedback. A few years ago the standard behavior of the Questions pages in Lesson was in fact what you wish. The sequence was: Question page (with question text and choices etc.). Next screen showing feedback on its own. If correct response, move on to next page; if incorrect go back to question page with text. As I use the Lesson module mainly for very brief material presentation and self-assessment questions, and as feedback is all important for me, I found it anti-pedagogic to display the feedback on its own, so that the student could no longer see the question text and their selected choice. This is why I insisted that feedback should be displayed on the same page as the question text and question choices . For the same reason I would find it strange to have the display you suggest: FEEDBACK QUESTION TEXT QUESTIONS & STUDENT'S RESPONSE It is not logical to have FEEDBACK displayed before QUESTION TEXT and RESPONSES. I quite understand your point of view. You apparently display a lot of text on question pages, and then ask a question at the bottom, etc. As I said at the beginning, because in the Lesson module you can use Question pages for a variety of uses, there is no display which will fit all types of activity. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Text: I have only used the lesson module for 1.5 but the answers may be helpful. On the lesson setup screen, you choose what percentage the lesson should be graded out of.  Typically I use 100%. For each individual question you select a number of points, this is to weigh the questions when calculating the total.  Then the number correct is divided by the total and the percent (out of the total possible percent you set earlier) is given. For the pages where you want text but no response, just a 'continue' you should use a branch table, this is basically a window where you enter text, and the student selects a button (one or several) that redirect him to a new page.  (i.e. continue -> next page, or four buttons go to page 1, go to page 2 etc..) Hope this was helpful.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary Thanks for the response. No, it never got resolved.  The problem was a missing item on the drop-down list of options, details of which escape me at present - I think it was that it offered a random selection from content pages but not from questions, although the whole point of a cluster is to cluster question pages.  It seems to work by selecting the page option.  Mind you, since then we've upgraded to 2.8 so it might now be OK, but we have finished creating the course so it will be the next course in which we'll discover any changes.
